DEATH
Name:   Peter REISBECK
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. Dec. 19, 1918
               Peter REISBECK a well known and highly respected citizen of Woodsfield route 3, died at about 5 o’clock Monday morning December 16, 1918, aged 71 years, after an illness of about two weeks. He leaves to mourn his death his wife and five children, one son and four daughters. The funeral was held Wednesday morning at Miltonsburg, Ohio. 
 
1918
Robinson, Clara O.
d: Dec. 19, 1918
 
1918
DEATH
Name:   Edsell T. HAWKS
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, December 1918
               “There are gains for all our                                    losses,
               There are balms for all our pains,
               But when youth, the dream,                                   departs,
               It takes something form our                                   hearts,
               And it never comes again.”
Edsell T. HAWKS, son of Mr. Homer HAWKS and deceased wife Alma HAWKS, was born in Jerusalem, Ohio, September 17, 1904. He died at Lewisville, R. R. 1 on December 20, 1918, bringing his total age to 14 years, 3 months, and 3 days. He was taken with a slight headache a few days ago, which however turned into violent pains in the spine and head and brought his young days to a rapid close. How often are we not faced by death in this life. We always tremble and totter in fear before it and it is well that we do for it is our greatest enemy. Quickly it is upon us - - to some are given days of thought and penitence before it comes, to others it comes on the wings of eagles. Whether we desire it or not we must accept it. The Materialist accepts it stoically, the atheist with alarm, the thoughtless with fright; the Christian alone can meet it as a challenge with honor, for to him have been given the weapons, against which death cannot survive. It often surprises him that it comes so early but his surprise is only the signal to get out his “sword of the Spirit” and to put on his “shield of faith” and against such spiritual armor of defense and offense, death cannot and never will prevail. On the cross our Savior showed us what “faith, hope and love” can do against death and we are true followers if we learn from him.
               Such were our thoughts when the neighbors collected on Sunday afternoon, Dec. 22, 1918, to pay last respects and reverence to the memory of one, who though only 14 years of age, was missed, when he died. He was a quiet boy to the outward observer, but whistling and singing when roaming abroad in solitude. We cannot but praise him when we think that of his fourteen years he had gone seven to Sunday School without voluntarily missing a single service. He was to receive a diploma for this faithfulness. We are sorry that he died before he had received it. He leaves behind many mourning friends and relatives. First among whom is his stepmother, who was as good to him as Lincoln’s stepmother was to the young Abraham LINCOLN. He was taken to Lewisville after memorial services at the house, from there he was taken to Lowell, Ohio, where he was buried beside his mother.
               Do no sinful action,
               Speak no angry word:
               Ye belong to Jesus,
               Children of the Lord.
               Christ is kind and gentle,
               Christ is pure and true,
               And his little children,
               Should be holy too.    
                                                 P. S.
 
1918
DEATH
Name: Henry Michael SMITH
Source: Newspaper clipping,  Dec. 1918
Provided by Eloise Lumbatis January
 
What is death? ‘Tis to be free,
No more to love or hope or fear,
To join th great equality:
All, all alike are humbled there,
The mighty grave wraps, lord and slave.
Nor pride, nor poverty dares come
Within that refuge-house, -the tomb.
               Such may, or may not have been the thoughts of Henry M. Smith, when he was called from this earth on Friday, December 13, 1918. At least such is the true nature of death. And such is its first function. Naked we are born into this life, and naked we leave it again, stripped of everything material or unspiritual. Nothing enters the great beyond, but what we are at your last breath. If you are a saint, as a saint you embark across the Stygian waters of the unknown; if you are a reprobate sinner, as a reprobate sinner you go across. There is an equality in death and again there is not. Equality since we all must share alike death’s bitterness. No equality since there are some who die a hopeful death and others who die a hopeless death.
               Let us hope with all his friends, that our beloved henry M. Smith died a hopeful death. If ever there was a man worthy to be called an optimist, it was he, and I believe, he was an optimist with his last breath too. Can we who are yet among those who are called living hope for a greater recommendation?
               The deceased was born December 17, 1884, in Wayne township, Monroe county, Ohio. For many years he resided at Miltonsburg. Among surviving near relatives are his mother, Mrs. Christina C. Claus and one sister, Mrs. Mary E. Dougherty, of Pittsburgh. His father, two brothers and one sister have gone before him to the grave. His father, Michael Smith, died November 22, 1904. Hi brothers, john W. Smith, died March 1, 1908, and George F. Smith, died November 12, 1908. His sister, Mrs. Christina steed, died June 1, 1911.
               He was baptized an Evangelical christian by Rev. Samuel Egger. During his early youth he went to school at Duff’s College, Pittsburg, Pa., from where he graduated in 1903. He became a member of faculty of that institution. He resigned his position there and took a more remunerative on with the Waverly Oil Works of Pittsburgh. On account of failing health he was compelled to discontinue this work and retired to his home at miltonsburg, Ohio, where he spent to remainder of his life. As a sufferer he was a rare example. Brave and cheerful. Anyone in the locality can testify to his sunny disposition an spontaneous happy spirits. many, many of us will miss him, now that he is gone to his reward.
               Other surviving relatives are his stepfather, Justus Claus, three nephews, four nieces and a host of loyal friends and neighbors.
               He was interred at the old Woodsfield cemetery beside the other missing members of the family on December 16, 1918, where he sleeps to awake again at the day of summons.
 
“I go to life and not to death,
   From darkness to life’s native sky,
I go from sickness and from pain,
   To health and immortality.
Let our farewell then, be tearless
   Since too, I bid farewell to tears;
Write this day of my departure
Festive in your coming years.
I go from poverty to wealth,
   From rags to raiment, angel-fair,
From the pale leanness of this flesh
   To beauty such as saints shall wear.”
                                                            P. S.
 
1918

DEATH
Name:   Justina NEUHART
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 9, 1919
               Justina NEUHART, aged about thirty years, died at her home at Los Angeles, California, Sunday, January 5, 1919. Deceased is a daughter of Mr. Daniel NEUHART formerly of this place, and a sister of Mrs. C. F. BOTT and niece of Mayor L. P. NEUHART of Woodsfield. 
 
1919
DEATH
Name:   Henry WITTENBROOK
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. Jan. 9, 1919
               Mr. Henry WITTENBROOK was born in Wheeling, West Virginia, November 24, 1843, and died January 2, 1919, at Mantua, Ohio, after an illness of 13 months. In the year 1871, on the 30th of November he was united in marriage to Miss Theresa JOHNSON who ten years ago on May 27, preceded him to the great beyond. When yet an infant he was baptized into the Lutheran Church and remained faithful to his Master throughout his life. The deceased was a resident of Woodsfield for many years, only after the death of his wife did he leave this locality and live with his children. He leaves to mourn his death five children, Forrest, John, and Stella WITTENBROOK of Mantua, Ralph WITTENBROOK of Wallington, Ohio and Margaret WITTENBROOK of Alma, Nebraska, besides several brothers and other relatives and a host of friends. Funeral services were conducted Monday afternoon at one o’clock, the Reverend A. H. KNIPPING of the Evangelical Church of this place officiating. Burial was at Hope cemetery. 
 
1919
DEATH
Name:   Morrie CARPENTER
Source: Monroe County death records
and        The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. Jan. 9, 1919
               Morrie CARPENTER, the six-year-old son of Oliver and Civilla CARPENTER of Calais, Ohio, died December 23, 1918, after a short illness from pneumonia. Morrie was an exceptionally bright little boy and enjoyed the love of all who knew him whether old or young. The death of this child is a severe blow to the parents and the brother and sister that are left. The writer can sympathize with the parents, having passed through the same sad affliction and would cite them to Him who said “Suffer little children, and forbid them not, to come unto me; for of such is the kingdom of heaven,” for consolation. 
 
1918
Longacher, Anthony
d: Dec. 29, 1918
1919
Carpenter, Margaret J.
d: 1919
 
1919
DEATH
Name:   Louis STOEHR
Source: Monroe county death records
and        The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. Jan. 9, 1919
               Louis STOEHR, aged 57 years, died Monday morning, January 6, 1919. Sunday evening with a neighbor and until at the time of starting home he was in his usual health, but upon starting became ill from some cause and kept on getting worse until about nine o’clock Monday morning when he expired. Mr. Stoehr had lived all his life in Woodsfield and was a good citizen, industrious and honest and enjoyed the respect of those with whom he had to do. He leaves a wife and several children. The funeral will be held this Thursday afternoon at 2 o’clock and the services will be conducted by the pastor, Reverend A. H. KNIPPING.

Isaac J. Baker

James A. Brown

1919
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Ottilia F. WAY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. Jan. 16, 1919
               Mrs. Ottilia F. OBLINGER WAY, aged 79 years, died at her home on South Main street Monday morning, January 13, 1919, after an illness of several months.
               Deceased was born at Malaga, Ohio and has resided in Monroe County, Ohio all her life. For many years she lived at Miltonsburg, Ohio moving from there to Woodsfield. Her maiden name was OBLINGER. She was first married to Mr. Peter DORR who died many years ago. A few years since she married Mr. William S. WAY who also preceded her in death.
               Mrs. Way was a very intelligent lady and a good neighbor and friend always looking on the merciful side of any conditions that came before her, free from unkind criticism and charitable to all. During her life she was an unfaltering member of the Catholic Church, yet broad in her views, allowing all others to believe as they thought best.
               She leaves one sister Mrs. Louis HOEFFLER and three brothers, C. L. OBLINGER of Lewisville, and  Clement OBLINGER of Warren, Ohio, and   Charles OBLINGER of Lancaster, PA, besides a number of other near relatives and many friends.
               The funeral services were held Wednesday morning and were conducted at the Catholic Church by the Reverend Frances SEEBER.
               We join in sympathy with her relatives and friends. May she rest in peace. 
1919
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Rosa YOHO
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. Jan. 16, 1919
               Mrs. Rosa YOHO, daughter of Jacob and Louisa FOEHRENBACH, was born near Woodsfield, Ohio, April 13, 1887, and died at Drumright, Oklahoma, January 7, 1919, at the age of 31 years, eight months and 24 days. On December 27, 1904, she was united in marriage to Mr. Melville YOHO and to this union were born two children, Vada YOHO, aged 10, and Reuben YOHO, aged 7. Death was the result of an attack of pneumonia. She leaves to mourn her early and sudden death her husband and two children, father and mother, two brothers, George W. and Walter M. FOEHRENBACH, and one sister, Mrs. Clara BUCHANAN. Also a large number of relatives and friends. The funeral took place Monday afternoon, January 13 from the residence of her parents. Burial at Buchanan cemetery. Reverend A. H. KNIPPING of the Evangelical Church at Woodsfield, conducted the funeral.

1919
DEATH
Name:   Pvt. Clemence G. CLAUS
Source: Newspaper clipping, Feb. 1919
Collection of Gilbert Claus
               Private Clemence G. Claus was the son of Frederick and Caroline HAFFNER CLAUS of near Miltonsburg, Ohio. He was born there July 11, 1895, near Monroefield, Ohio, and was baptized and confirmed according to the rites of the Evangelical Church. He was selected for service in the United States Army on July 22, 1918. The many hardships of our soldier boys across the sea was also a portion of his experiences. Finally the Armistice was signed. Yet to some signing of the Armistice was not as assurance of the safe return of their loved one. On the fourth of February 1919, the household of Mr. and Mrs. Fred CLAUS was shocked and grieved upon the receipt of a letter from Captain Spier containing the sad news that their boy whom they had all thought well and contented in Grancem had died four weeks before.
               Private Clemence G. CLAUS left the world behind and entered into eternal rest on January 12, 1919. He had been suffering form meningitis. He had reached the tender age of 23 years, six months and one day old. The end came at Dernbach, Germany; where he was also laid to rest in the First Division cemetery. This however was to be his final resting place. The remains were removed from their first resting place and brought to his native country. On July 19, 1920, the body of the deceased arrived at Woodsfield, Ohio to be buried in the family lot in St. Peter’s Evangelical cemetery at Miltonsburg, Ohio on July 25, 1920.
               The deceased patriot and loyal soldier leaves behind his father and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Fed CLAUS; three sisters; Mrs. Fred (Anna Catherina) CHRISTMAN; Mrs. Herman (Minnie Caroline) EGGER; and Mrs. Elmer (Clara Louisa) CHRISTMAN; four brothers, Edwin Fredrick CLAUS and Benjamin Henry CLAUS residing in Iowa; Leroy Alfred CLAUS and Gilbert John CLAUS are living at the home of their parents.         
               The funeral took place Sunday, July 25, 1920. Services in the Church began at 2 p.m. The local preacher delivered the sermon. The American Legion was present and took over the services at the grave under Captain MOONEY and Chaplain Charles JONES. The bugler was Robert DIEHL. The pallbearers were ex-soldiers Chester RELLER, Grover KNAPP, Joseph REIGHT, Bernard KRESS, and Nicholas REIMENSCHNEIDER.
               Rev. MUECKE then officiated in laying the body in its final resting place in the Evangelical Miltonsburg cemetery. 
1919
Hines, Minerva
d: Feb. 1, 1919

d: Feb. 1, 1919

Turner, Thomas E
d: Feb. 2, 1919

Names: Mr. Benjamin A. SCHELL
and        Miss Bessie BILLMAN

1919
DEATH
Name:   William M. WILLIAMS
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Feb. 13, 1919
               William M. WILLIAMS, aged 64 years, died at his home in Woodsfield February 8, 1919, after a severe illness of several days from pneumonia. Deceased was born on a farm at Round Bottom, Ohio and grew to manhood and lived at  and near that place until in 1900 when he moved to Woodsfield. He obtained a good education and taught school a number of years, and for two terms served as County school examiner. He held the office of justice of the peace in Green township and after coming to Woodsfield was deputy County auditor for three years. At the close of the last named duties he started The Sentinel and had been engaged in the printing and publishing business since. He leaves a widow and five children. The funeral took place Monday and was conducted by the members of Woodsfield Lodge No. 377 I. O. O. F., with the Reverend E. R. ROMIG as minister. 
 
1919
DEATH
Name:    Barbara WAGONHEIM
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
 Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. Feb. 27, 1919
               Mrs. Barbara WAGONHEIM aged about 60 years, wife of John M. WAGONHEIM of Newark, died February 21, 1919. Deceased was a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick KINDELBERGER of Woodsfield route four.

Name:   Mrs. Mary A. BUCHANAN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. Feb. 27, 1919
Collection of Lena Kahrig Pettit
               Mrs. Mary A. BUCHANAN, aged 89 years, two months and 11 days, died at her home in Beallsville, Ohio February 22, 1919. Deceased had been a member of the Presbyterian Church for many years, and was held in high esteem by those who knew her. The remains were taken to the Buchanan Church Tuesday and buried by the side of her husband, C. S. BUCHANAN, who preceded her many years ago. Eight children are left.

1919XXXXX
DEATH
Name:   Herman ACKERMAN
Source: Newspaper clipping and
St. John’s Church records, February 1919
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
               Herman ACKERMAN, the subject of this sketch, was born on the 15th day of February, 1837, in Landefeld, near Spangenburg Gur-Hessan, Germany. His parents being interested more in his spiritual than in his material welfare had him confirmed in the Christian faith while yet in the Fatherland on May 21st, 1851. In the year 1857, on the 11th day of April, he left the Fatherland and sailed to America and landed in Wheeling, West Virginia, on July 22nd of the same year. On March 16, 1862, he was united in marriage to Mary NIESZ, and to this union seven children was born, three sons and four daughters. Anna, the eldest of the children, preceded him to the better land on March 1, 1896. He leaves to mourn, his devoted wife and the following children, John ACKERMAN near home; Henry ACKERMAN of Somerton, Ohio; Benjamin ACKERMAN, of Donora, Pennsylvania; Mrs. Jacob CHRISTMAN, near home; Mrs. John CHRISTMAN, of Calais, Ohio; and Mrs. John SEEBACH, of Alliance. Also twenty-nine grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. The first ten years of their married life was spent in Benwood and Wheeling, West Virginia. In March, 1872, they moved from Wheeling to Ohio near Monroefield on the farm known as the Jacob BERTRAM farm; here they lived dividing their joys and sorrows till in the fall of 1889, when they moved to the farm on which he died, which was on the 27th day of February, 1919, being at the time of his death 82 years and 12 days old. In November last he took sick with that dreaded disease pneumonia from which he never recovered sinking gradually until death relieved him. During his illness he was tenderly cared for by his loving wife and children and grandchildren, but more especially by two grandchildren, Clara BINTZ and Viola BINTZ, who were constantly at his bedside doing all that loving hands could do to restore him to health, but to no avail, He was laid away to await the resurrection morn on Sunday, March 2nd, in the St. John’s Middle Church cemetery, followed by a large concourse of friends and relatives, amid  beautiful floral offerings. The funeral was conducted by his former pastor, the Reverend Paul SALESKE, of Chicago, Illinois.
Tis hard to break the tender cord
When Love has bound the heart,
Tis hard so hard to speak the words
Must we forever part.
Dearest loved one we have laid thee,
In the peaceful grave’s embrace.
But thy memory will be cherished
Till we see thy heavenly face.
We miss thee from our home, dear,
We miss thee from thy place,
A shadow o’er our life is cast.
We miss the sunshine of thy face,
We miss thy kind and willing hand,
Thy fond and earnest care,
Our home is dark without thee
We miss thee everywhere.
Oh, then let us all be ready,
When the call for us shall come,
To meet you dear father
In that happy, happy, land.
A FRIEND. 
1919
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Ellen TRUEX
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. Feb. 20, 1919
               Mrs. Ellen McCAMMON TRUEX, aged 75 years, relict of Leander TRUEX, died at her home on North Main street Tuesday morning February 18, after an illness of several days. Deceased was a member of the Presbyterian Church. The funeral services will be held today, Thursday, interment in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio. 
 
1919
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Ellen TRUEX
Source: Newspaper dated Feb. 18, 1919
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
               On February 18, 1919, the pure and gentle spirit of Mrs. Ellen TRUEX was called from this world to the celestial home above, being in her 73rd year. The subject of this sketch, formerly Miss Ellen McCAMMON, was born in the year 1846, on a farm now the home of her brother, Alexander McCAMMON, of near Kerr Station. She was the youngest daughter of Robert and Jane McCAMMON, and one of a family of six children of which the oldest brother, Alexander, is the only surviving member. Two brothers, Robert and Samuel, and two sister, Mrs. Jane BROWN and Mrs. Sarah STIMPERT having preceded her to that hem where there is no parting and no more good byes said. Mrs. Truex was formerly one of Monroe County’s progressive school teachers and will always be kindly remembered by many of the middle aged men and women of today for whom she did so much by always setting a good example of patriotism and morality. She always had a word of welcome for all who came to visit her home and there was nothing gave her more pleasure than to have her friends around her enjoying a social chat with those near and dear to her. She will be sadly missed by her many friends and relatives. 
 
1919
DEATH
Name:   Rosina CHRISTMAN
Source: Monroe County death records
and        Evangelical church records
Lewisville, Ohio, March 2, 1919
               Rosina PFALZGRAF was born February 22, 1834; daughter of George Michael, Jr., and Elizabeth DIEHL PFALZGRAF; spouse of Philip H. CHRISTMAN; married April 21, 1854; Rosina died March 2, 1919; burial in St. John’s Middle Church cemetery, near Lewisville, Ohio.
1919
DEATH
Name:   Edward YOCKEY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. March 6, 1919
               Another old veteran of Monroe County, Ohio has gone to attend roll call where there is no war or rebel prisoners. Edward YOCKEY was born near Miltonsburg, Ohio in 1841, the son of Lawrence and Elizabeth YOCKEY, and died from dropsy and heart failure at Smithland, Iowa, February 19, 1919. He enlisted in August 1862 and served until June, 1865 in Company “C,” 116th O. V. I. He was wounded in June 1864, and was a prisoner for 9 months in  Andersonville, Georgia where over 14,000 of our brave boys died from hunger and exposure. In 1865, he went to Smithland, Iowa and married a Miss Smith. He leaves to mourn his death his wife, one son and two daughters, one brother, John YOCKEY. He was an uncle of J. H. and L. P. LANG, Miss Lottie LANG, Mrs. P. SCHUMACHER, Mrs. Frank SCHUMACHER, and Mrs. Charles BURKHART of this place, and many other relatives and old soldier friends. Rest in peace until we meet again.
             LOUIS SULSBERGER,
             Late Corporal Co., “C,” 116 O. V. I.
 
1919      XXXXX
DEATH
Name:   Albert D. McVEY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. March 13, 1919
               Once more the death angel has visited our home and took from us a loved one. Albert D. McVEY was born April 17, 1865, and departed this life January 28, 1919. He was united in marriage to Clarinda DOUGHERTY. To this union was born seven children. His wife and two daughters preceded him to the great beyond. He leaves to mourn his departure three sons, two daughters and one sister. His death was caused from tuberculosis. Everything was done to help him, but to no avail. He will be sadly missed by all.                             M.  K.  
 
1919

1919
DEATH
Name:   Lydia L. CLAUS, nee KILBURN
Source: Monroe County death records
and        Newspaper clipping
and        St. John’s Church records
Lewisville, Ohio, March 1919
Collection of Beryl Christman Claus
               Lydia Louise CLAUS, wife of Walter Charles CLAUS, died Sunday, March 9, 1919, age 21 years, 5 months, and 12 days, after an illness of a few days of the influenza. She bore her sickness and affliction without murmur or complaint and sweetly fell asleep to wake in her blest home. She was born September 25, 1897, the daughter of Gustav F. KILBURN and Mary KAHRIG. On April 9, 1911, she was confirmed at the St. John’s Evangelical Church. She was a member of the Sunday School all the days of her life. On October 31, 1916, she was united in marriage to Walter C. CLAUS. Short was the duration of the happy union. Like a thief of the night the news came from the clear sky of her death. She leaves to mourn her death, husband, Walter C. CLAUS; one son, Wilbert Walter CLAUS, aged two years; one daughter, Grace Lydia CLAUS, aged 11 hours; father and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Gus KILBURN; 2 sisters, Estella KILBURN and Sylvia KILBURN, and two brothers, Freeman KILBURN and William KILBURN, besides  the many friends who love her. She will be missed by us and all who knew her because she was so kind and pleasant to everyone and the work that she has done will bring her memory back to us. She was laid to rest in St. John’s Middle Church cemetery, near Lewisville, Ohio with the Reverend MEISENHEIMER officiating. 
 
1919
DEATH
Name:   Lewis G. ROSE
Source: Newspaper clapping, March 1919
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
               A sad death occurred at the Lewis G. ROSE place 10 miles from the town of Bloomfield, Iowa.  Mr. L. G. ROSE became a suicide on last Wednesday forenoon, March 12, 1919. Lewis ROSE was born at Lewisville, Ohio, May 23, 1863. In 1883 the family moved to Hornick, Iowa. Here he married on May 19, 1885, to Lusetta SMITH his present mourning widow. In 1904 the L. G. ROSE family moved to this neighborhood.
               Their union was blessed with seven children: Mrs. Bertha LANGE; Herman LANGE, Sergeant in the United States of America in Germany; Edna; Everett; Lawrence; Amelia; and Arthur ROSE all at home; and 3 grandchildren, two brothers and five sisters mourn his sad and untimely death. His age being 55 years 8 months and 11 days.
               Lewis ROSE has the reputation of being honest and true neighbor, and friend. The entire neighborhood speak well of him. He was also a true Christian. He was a regular attendant of public worship. He loved to do good work and charity. What caused him to end his life nobody knows because there was no reason for it, and no family trouble whatever. But he was so sickly and his health had been failing for some time. The only explanation we can find is this: He did it in a state of melancholy in a depressed spirit.
               Short funeral services were held at the house on this week Tuesday, after which the burial followed. After the burial the Reverend A. OLLENBURG conducted funeral services at the First Trinity Lutheran Church.
1919
Claus, Lydia L.
d: Mar. 9, 1919
1919
Wehr, Maude V.
d: Mar. 10, 1919
 
1919
Stewart, Sarah
d: Mar. 13, 1919
1919
Yost, John I.
d: Mar. 13, 1919
1919
Freda Buckio
d- March 14, 1919

DEATH
Name:     Mrs. Hulda BROWN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., April 3, 1919
               Mrs. Hulda Brown, aged 28 years, wife of John Brown, died March 22 at a Zanesville, Ohio hospital following an operation. The deceased was a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles CARPENTER of near Calais, Ohio. Besides her husband she is survived by a daughter seven years of age, her parents, seven sisters and two brothers, Howard CARPENTER with the United States army in France and Albert CARPENTER of Calais. Interment was made in the Calais cemetery.
 
1919
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Eliza Jane JACKSON
Source: Monroe County death records
and        The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., April 10, 1919
               Mrs. Eliza Jane JACKSON, aged about 70 years, relict of the late Lewis JACKSON, died at her home on Neuhart ridge April 8, 1919. Three children are left. The funeral will take place at the Neuhart church this Thursday, April 10, 1919, morning at 10 o’clock.

Source: Monroe county death records
and        The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. May 1, 1919
               Alexander CRONIN of near Edwina, Ohio died April 26, 1919, aged 81 years. He leaves a wife and seven children, one brother and two sisters. He had been a faithful member of the Christian Church since early manhood. He was the father of Mr. Elmer E. CRONIN and Mrs. Riley SMITH of Woodsfield.

DEATH
Name:     Mrs. Eva Ann YOUNG
Source:   Monroe County death records
and          The Spirit of Democracy Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, May 8, 1919
            Mrs. Eva Ann YOUNG, aged 71 years, died Friday night, May 2, 1919, after an illness of several months.  Deceased had been a resident of Woodsfield all her life, being the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph POOL.  She leaves a husband and one son and one brother Mr. John POOL of Lisbon, Ohio.  She had been a member of the M. E. Church for many years.  The funeral took place Sunday.

DEATH
Name:    Isaac DeLONG
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., May 22, 1919
            Isaac DeLONG, aged about 80 years, died April 17, 1919, at his home on James’ run. He leaves a widow and several children. He was the father of Jesse DeLONG of Woodsfield.
 
1919
DEATH
Name:    Forrest F. FORD
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., May 22, 1919
            The funeral of Forrest F. Ford was held Friday afternoon and was conducted by Monroe Lodge No. 189, F. & A. M., with the Reverend August H. KNIPPING as officiating minister. Forrest FORD was born near Woodsfield on April 28, 1857, and died May 13th at his home in Indianapolis, Indiana, after an illness of several months from Bright’s disease. He was married to Miss Elizabeth YOCKEY of this county June 19, 1906, and leaves two children, Clyde and Elizabeth FORD, to comfort their mother. Forrest Ford was the first express messenger on the Bellaire & Southwestern Railway, now known as the O. R. & W. Railway, and will be remembered by many railroaders and business men all along that road. He followed this line of work until a short time prior to his death, his last run being on the Pennsylvania road. Forrest Ford was a member of the Christian church, Masonic, Woodmen of the World, L. O. O. F. and Independent Order of American lodges. Those attending the funeral from a distance were the widow and children of Indianapolis; Jacob YOCKEY and family and Mrs. Philip GERTLER of Ozark, Ohio; William YOCKEY of Akron, Ohio; Charles YOCKEY of Newark; Mrs. Martha FORD and Mrs. Catherine BARNES of Barnesville.
 
1919
DEATH
Name:  John PFALZGRAF
Source: Monroe County death records
and      The Spirit of Democracy     
Woodsfield, Ohio, May 26, 1919
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
            John PFALZGRAF died May 10, 1919. He was born February 11, 1837, in Seneca township, Monroe County, Ohio, and was a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Michael PFALZGRAF who came to this country in 1832 from Alsace Lorraine. John grew to manhood on the farm which was government land when his father secured it and is now owned by the youngest son, George PFALZGRAF.
            On February 17, 1864, he was married to Miss Catherine CHRISTMAN. The next year he moved to the farm originally contained 670 acres. The land was entered in 1831, and the patent deed was signed by Andrew JACKSON. Mr. Pfalzgraf was an industrious farmer and the farm became a valuable one, and especially in the last few years when it was found to have exceptional deposits of coal under it.
            Mr. and Mrs. Pfalzgraf raised a family of twelve children, all of whom with his widow are living except two, William PFALZGRAF, who died at the age of five years and George PFALZGRAF, who was killed in an accident in Pittsburgh several years ago. Those living are: Mrs. Barbara WALTON, of Round Bottom; Jacob A. PFALZGRAF, of Coyle, Oklahoma; John PFALZGRAF, of Clarington, Route 3; Mrs. Louise METGZER, of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; Alex PFALZGRAF, at home; Mrs. Christina CHRISTMAN, Bowie, Texas; Lewis E. PFALZGRAF of Round Bottom; Samuel PFALZGRAF of Cameron; Ben PFALZGRAF of Greely, Colorado, and Miss Mary PFALZGRAF at Boulder, Colorado.
            In 1873, Mr. Pfalzgraf was elected Infirmary Director and served the county in that capacity for six years. In 1889, he was elected County Commissioner which office he held for six years and nine months, being present of the board. In office he used the same practical common sense and good judgment that characterized his own business transactions.
            For the thirty years preceding his death he had been a member of Clarington Lodge No. 346 K. of P. and was a strong advocate of the high principles of that fraternal organization.
            When a youth, he was confirmed in the Lutheran Church at Middle Church but after moving to the eastern part of the county had a little opportunity to attend the services of the Church of his chosen faith. In personality, Mr. Pfalzgraf was open hearted, kind and friendly and many young people long since in homes of their own remember the good times the hospitable home afforded years ago.
            For the past years, Mr. Pfalzgraf had been in rather poor health, yet considering years and infirmities his active will refused to submit where a man of less stamina would have yielded. He died at his home near Altitude Saturday morning, May 10th, and the funeral services were held at the home and at Pleasant Ridge Church the following Monday, conducted by the Reverend C. H. ROE, of the M. E. Church at Clarington. Interment in the Pleasant Ridge cemetery by the side of his son, George.
 
1919
Paulus, Mary A.
d: June 2, 1919
 
1919XXXXX
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Henry ACKERMAN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., June 5, 1919
            A serious accident, which proved to be fatal to one of the party, occurred on the National paved highway near the John ISRAEL homestead last Sunday evening, May 27.  Mr. Henry ACKERMAN, his wife and several children were driving an automobile headed west when in some unexplainable manner the machine became uncontrollable and ran off the paving on to the berm.
            When the driver tried to right the machine the front wheels struck a high place in the curbing, upsetting the auto and its occupants were all thrown into a frightened heap.
            Mrs. Ackerman, former Louise CHRISTMAN, was very seriously injured by having several bones broken. She was taken to her home in an ambulance and death occurred Tuesday night, never having regained consciousness.
            Mr. Ackerman and the remaining members of his family were painfully though not seriously hurt.
            The Ackermans are farmer folks living between Somerton, Ohio and Malaga, Ohio and a prominent and well-to-do people. Mrs. Ackerman was 58 years of age.
            Burial was at Somerton Southern cemetery, Somerton, Ohio.
 
1919
MARRIAGE
Names: Mr. Clarence LAFFERRE
and         Miss Edna Spence
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, June 5, 1919
            Miss Edna SPENCE became the bride of Mr. Clarence LAFFERRE last Wednesday night. The ceremony was performed at 8:30 o’clock in the parsonage parlors with the Rev. P. D. LASELLES, rector of the Presbyterian church, officiating. After the ceremony Mrs. Lafferre’s girl friends gave them a very pleasant shower at the bride’s home on South Main street. Mrs. Lafferre has been an efficient saleslady in W. H. Jackson & Son’s store for the past four years. Mr. Lafferre is employed at the Loffland Brothers machine plant. The principals to this happy affair have hosts of friends who are extending congratulations.

1919XXXXX
DEATH
Name:   Anna Marie BINTZ
Source: Monroe County death records
and      Newspaper clipping, July 1919
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig  
            Anna Marie PFALZGRAF BINTZ, a daughter of George and Sophia KILBURN PFALZGRAF, was born in Seneca township, Monroe County, Ohio, October 31, 1884. She was brought up and confirmed in the German Evangelical Church known as St. John’s Middle Church, of Summit township, Lewisville, Ohio.
            On February 2, 1909, she was married to Elmer BINTZ. Five children were born, all girls.
            Anna Marie was ill with tuberculosis of lungs in 1916. She went to Mt. Vernon to a sanitarium for some time, but her mother’s love for her dear children was more than she could stand getting homesick for them she came home again in Malaga township, after about six weeks of absence, though apparently much improved, but only for a short time. She gradually grew worse till on the morning of July 4, 1919.
            She leaves to mourn her devoted husband, Elmer BINTZ, and five small children, Sophia, Leona, Rose, Freda, and Esther BINTZ; father and mother, three sisters and one brother, besides a large number of near relatives and friends.
            Services were conducted by the Rev. S. E. KAETZEL, of Clarington, Ohio.
            Burial was made in the German M. E. cemetery near Monroefield, Ohio on Sunday morning July 6, 1919.

DEATH
Name:     Margaret A. BOLON
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., July 24, 1919
            Margaret A. BOLON died at the home of her daughter, Mrs. O. McCABE at 1035 Cherry street, Wheeling, July 16, 1919. Services were held at the home of her daughter July 17 conducted by Dr. ALLAN of Fourth street M. E. Church, Wheeling. The remains were brought to her old home at Beallsville, Ohio, Friday, July 18th, and buried in the cemetery at that place, services being conducted at the grave by the Reverend MARTY of the Methodist Episcopal church. She leaves surviving her one daughter, Mrs. O. McCABE, a sister Harriet BOLON and a brother Alex. BOLON. She was a life long member of the M. E. church.

1919
DEATH
Name:   Joseph E. NALLEY
Source: Monroe County death records
and        The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. July 24, 1919
            Joseph E. NALLEY was born June 13, 1841, near Woodsfield, Ohio, and departed this life July 17, 1919, being at the time of his death 78 years, one month, and four days of age. He was united in marriage with Miss Sarah J. FLAN AGAN July 10, 1864. To this union a family of seven children were born, one son and six daughters. He leaves to mourn his departure his beloved companion and the following children: Mrs. Louisa C. BAKER of Round Bottom, Ohio, Mrs. Emma J. STRICKLING, Mrs. Virginia V. BURGBACKER, Mr. John L. B. NALLEY, Mrs. Anna BENJAMIN of Woodsfield, and Miss Elizabeth J. NALLEY, Mrs. Ida S. DeVOE and grandson Earl DeVOE of the home. Seventeen grandchildren, five great grandchildren, several brothers and sisters and many other relatives and friends. The funeral was held at his late home on Eastern avenue Saturday, July 19, at three o’clock conducted by the Rev. E. R. ROMIG. Interment in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.

After the marriage a reception was held at the bride’s home and a large number of guests attended.

Deceased was a member of the Catholic church and one of the best read ladies in the vicinity. The funeral was held Tuesday conducted by the Rev. Francis SEEBER.

and          Mrs. Flora E. PURCELL
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 25, 1919
            Mr. J. M. WADE and Mrs. Flora E. PURCELL of Moundsville, West Virginia, were united in marriage at Akron, Ohio September 15, 1919. The ceremony was performed by the Reverend H. D. WELLS, pastor of the First Christian church of High street. Mrs. Wade is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry PRATT and was born in Woodsfield. Many friends of this place extend congratulations and wish Mr. and Mrs. Wade a happy and prosperous life. They will reside at Akron, Ohio.

1919   XXXXx
DEATH
Name:    M. H. McKELVEY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 25, 1919
            Milton H. McKELVEY, aged 63 years, died at Ozark, Ohio September 21, 1919. Deceased was born at New Castle, this county, at which place he grew to manhood. He was married to Miss Ella READ to which union two children were born - - Ewing, of Denver, Colorado, and Mrs. H. B. BROWN of Ozark at whose home he died. He also leaves two brothers - - Lee McKELVEY of Toronto, Ohio and Everett McKELVEY of Laings, besides his widow. Mr. McKelvey had been employed as machinist at Cleveland but ill health compelled him to quit his business and seek relief. The remains were brought to Woodsfield Monday and taken to the home of his sister-in-law Mrs. Lottie BEARDMORE where thy were tenderly cared for. The funeral services will be held at the home of Mrs. Beardmore this (Thursday) afternoon at two o’clock; interment in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.

1919
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Charles E. CHRISTMAN
Source: Monroe County death records
and         The Monroe County Beacon
Woodsfield, Ohio, December 1919
Collection of Wilda Heft Bartenschlag
            Laura Melinda CHRISTMAN, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marx BAKER, was born September 20, 1874, near Lewisville, Ohio. As an infant she received the sacrament of holy baptism according to the rites of the Evangelical Church. Later she renewed these baptismal vows in her confirmation.
             On October 15, 1898, she was united in holy wedlock with Mr. Charles E. CHRISTMAN, of near Lewisville, Ohio. What cannot be said with honesty of many professing Christians, can be said of her, the devoted wife and loving mother, as all her acquaintances knew her to be.
            For two weeks the deceased was suffering from typhoid fever. It finally pleased our Heavenly Father to call her from this world of care and to translate her into her eternal home. She was prepared to meet her Savior and glad of His advent. It was 1:10 o’clock last Friday morning, December 5, 1919, that she gave up the spirit, without a struggle.
            The deceased is survived by her husband, three sons, Sylvester, Harvey  and Charles CHRISTMAN; two sisters, Mrs. BRISTER, of Brister Station, and Mrs. Mary KING, of Pittsburg; four brothers, George, John and William BAKER, of  near Lewisville, and Louis BAKER of Pittsburg; besides many other relatives and friends.
            May our Heavenly Father strengthen the bereaved in this their hour of sadness. That is the prayer of all their friends.
            Funeral services were conducted last Sunday at the home and at St. John’s Evangelical Church of Summit township. The remains were laid to rest in the St. John’s Evangelical cemetery, near Lewisville. The Reverend Otto MUECKE, of Miltonsburg, conducted the services.
            The deceased had reached the age of 45 years, 2 months and 2 weeks. Thus are we called to our heavenly home in the midst of life. She died in her home near Lewisville, Ohio.
            May God, the great comforter, strengthen those who are left behind.                        Memento Mori!
 
1919

1920
MARRIAGE
Names:  Mr. Creed HARMON
and          Miss Ethel RING
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Jan. 1, 1920
            Mr. Creed HARMON and Miss Ethel RING were united in marriage at Woodsfield on Wednesday, December 24, 1919. The ceremony was performed by W. D. RICHNER, J. P., at 11 o’clock. After the ceremony the wedded couple returned to the bride’s home where a fine wedding supper was served at 6 o’clock to a number of invited relatives.
            Mr. and Mrs. Harmon were the recipients of several useful presents. Mr. Harmon is a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. P. HARMON of Graysville, Ohio. His bride is a daughter of Mrs. Anna RING. Both young people are members of good families and have the best wishes of their friends and relatives.
 
1920
DEATH
Name:     Mrs. Hugh CRAWFORD
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Jan. 1, 1920
            On Christmas Day relatives at this place received a message announcing the death of Mrs. Margaret CRAWFORD, widow of the late Hugh CRAWFORD, who died at Trees, Louisiana, at one o’clock Christmas morning, December 25, 1919. Mrs. Crawford was spending the winter with her daughter, Mrs. Aggie BOYER, at Trees, and took sick of acute indigestion several weeks ago from which she never entirely rallied. The remains were brought to the Crawford home on Maple avenue Saturday evening and the funeral took place Monday at two o o’clock p.m. Services were conducted at the home of her son, William CRAWFORD, by Rev. L. R. LAWTHER of St. Clairsville, assisted by Rev. P. D. LASELLES of Woodsfield after which the remains were laid to rest in Oaklawn cemetery beside her husband. The funeral was largely attended by relatives and friends from far and near, and the floral offering bore eloquent evidence of the splendid life she had lived.
            Mrs. Margaret CRAWFORD, whose maiden name was CRAIG, the daughter of William and Elizabeth CRAIG, was born in Woodsfield and was a member of one of our most highly respected pioneer families. She was a member of the Presbyterian church and a woman of many fine and endearing qualities. Her husband, Mr. Hugh CRAWFORD passed away two years ago last November. Three sons and four daughters survive: Andrew CRAWFORD of Woodruff, West Virginia; Thomas CRAWFORD of Woodsfield, Route one; William CRAWFORD of Woodsfield; Mrs. Mary HICKMAN of Colfax, Washington; Mrs. Maggie WILCOX of Cleveland, Ohio; Miss Delia CRAWFORD of Boville, Idaho, and Mrs. Aggie BOYER, of Trees, Louisiana. Also one brother and three sisters, Ezra D. CRAIG and Clara CRAWFORD of Woodsfield; Agnes MONROE and Nancy Jane AMOS (widow of the late Oliver AMOS) of Sidney, Ohio.
            The relatives have the sincere sympathy of many friends here and elsewhere in the county.
 
1920

1920
Sheets, William M.
d: Jan. 31, 1920
 
Dallas Gossage
Deaths
Dallas Gossage
     The funeral of Mr. Dallas Gossage was held at the home of his daughter,
Mrs. C.S. Wells at 217 South Sandusky street, Sunday afternoon with Rev.
A.A. Miller in charge of the services.  During the services Misses Leodna
Smith, Grace Williams and Mildred Price very beautifully sand "Beautiful
Isle of Somewhere," "Nearer My God To Thee" and "Shall We Gather at the
River."  The pall bearers were members of the A.I.U. order and were Messrs.
Charles Traxler, W. B. Clevenger, William Slack, Vic Hardin, William Smith
and Ed Benneman.  Burial at Oak Grove.
[Source: The Delaware Journal-Herald, Monday, February 2, 1920, p. 5]
 
Mr. Dallas Gossage
     Mr. Dallas Gossage, a former resident of this city died in Akron on
Thursday of celebrial hemorrhage. He is survived by his wife, two sons and
one daughter.
     Funeral services will be held from the residence of Mr. C. S. Wells,
No. 217 South Sandusky street Sunday afternoon at 2 o'clock with Rev. Ernest
Miller in charge.  Interment will be made in Oak Grove cemetery.
[Source: Delaware Journal-Herald, Delaware, Ohio, Saturday, January 31,
1920, p. 5]
 
1920
DEATHS
Names:   George L. GILLESPIE
and           Mrs. Bert TRUEX
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Feb. 5, 1920
            Two deaths, both caused by pneumonia occurred in the Gillespie-Truex family near this place within a few hours of each other. Last Friday morning, January 30, 1920, Mrs. Bert TRUEX died at her home near Altitude, Ohio. That night her father, Mr. George L. GILLISPIE, who was making his home with her, died of the same disease.
            The remains of Mrs. Truex were laid to rest at Mt. Carrick. The funeral of Mrs. Truex took place Tuesday and that of her father Wednesday, and the remains of her father at Pleasant Ridge cemetery by the side of his wife, who died several years ago.
            Both were very highly respected citizens.
 
1920
Winland, John

1920XXXXX
DEATH
Name:    Fred BLUM
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Feb. 5, 1920
            Fred BLUM, an aged and highly respected citizen of Switzerland township, Ohio died suddenly at his home Thursday, January 31, 1920. He had just recovered from an attack of pneumonia and was doing light work. He died while sitting in a chair and was in the 82 years of his age. He is survived by a wife, one son and one daughter, and numerous other relatives and friends.
 
1920
Pennell, Susanna
d: Feb. 8, 1920
1920

d: Feb. 8, 1920
 
1920
DEATH
Name:   Ludwig NEUHART
Source: Monroe county death records
Woodsfield, Ohio, February 8, 1920
            Ludwig NEUHART died February 8, 1920; born December 16, 1831, in Rumbach; father Valentin NEUHART; mother Catharina Elisabetha SCHNEIDER; spouse Amy Marie BOTT.
 
1920
DEATH
Name:    Mr. Chris STEELE
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Feb. 12, 1920
            Mrs. Minnie COPELAND, of Maple avenue received a message Tuesday announcing the death of Mr. Christian STEELE at his home west of Lewisville Tuesday morning. Mr. Steele, whose death was caused by ailments incident to old age, was about 84 years old, died February 10, 1920. His entire life was spent where he died, having lived with Jacob H. HAMILTON from childhood to manhood. Mrs. COPELAND left for Lewisville this (Wednesday) morning and will remain for the funeral.
 
1920
DEATH
Name:    Mr. Henry SCHUTTY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Feb. 12, 1920
            Mr. Henry SCHUTTY, an aged and retired business man of Clarington, Ohio passed away at his home here Friday evening at about 7:30 o’clock, after a lingering illness. He was taken to his bed about six weeks ago when he suffered a slight stroke of paralysis. His death had been expected for several days but came as a severe shock to the surviving relatives. Mr. Schutty was a pioneer of the town having engaged in business here about the year 1850 and continued until a few years ago, since which time he had been living a retired life. He was in the 89th year of his age and is survived by four daughters, his wife Elisabeth SCHUTTY, and one daughter having preceded him to the grave several years ago. Funeral services while not complete will likely be held Sunday with services at the Evangelical church with burial in the family lot in Clarington cemetery.
 
1920XXXXX
DEATH
Name:     Mrs. Sarah BARE
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio Thursday, Feb. 19, 1920
            Mrs. Sarah BARE, aged and well known citizen of this place, died February 4, 1920.
            Mrs. Sarah BARE was born at Shadyside, Ohio, August 17, 1842, and died February 4, 1920; aged 77 years, 5 months, and 14 days. She was united in marriage with Leander BARE, August 28, 1861, was converted under the ministry of the Reverend STARKEY and united with the M. E, church of Hannibal, Ohio.
            The deceased is survived by one daughter, Mrs. Allie VOEGTLY, with whom she made her home, and one son, A. L. BARE, of Cleveland, Ohio and two sisters, Mrs. Sue VOEGTLY, of Hannibal, and Mrs. F. L. PHILLIPS, of Barnesville. Her husband preceded her many years ago.
            The funeral was held on Friday afternoon and services were conducted by the Rev. I. E. WEBSTER at the home and interment was made in the family lot in the Harter cemetery beside her husband.
 
1920
Knowlton, Sarah
d: Feb. 12, 1920
1920
Weisend, Hannah K.
d: Feb. 12, 1920
 
1920XXXXX
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Mary BAKER, nee MEADE
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, OH Thursday, Feb. 19, 1920
            Miss Mary MEADE of Mechanicsburg, Ohio was born February 12, 1844. She was united in marriage with John M. BAKER who preceded her in death, September 8, 1912. To this union were born twelve children, five boys and seven girls, as follows: George M., James A., Otho O., Anna Laura, Margaret L., John F., Mollie L., Daisy D., Delcie R., Vincent Homer, Florence Viola and Sarah Eleanor BAKER, all of whom remain to mourn her death except George M. BAKER, who departed this life on November 2, 1917.
            She was a devoted member of the Church of Christ since early life. She departed this life February 13, 1920, being at the time of her death 70 years and one day old.
            Funeral services were conducted by the Reverend A. CALVERT of Antioch, where the remains were laid to rest in the Antioch cemetery.
1920
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Elizabeth REICH
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Feb. 19, 1920
            Mrs. Elizabeth REICH, wife of Andrew REICH, died at her home on Maple Avenue last Saturday morning, February 14, 1920, aft a long illness following a paralytic stroke, aged 71 years. She was the daughter of Henry and Elizabeth ACKERMAN CLAUS. She was a member of St. Paul’s Evangelical church at this place and a good woman, whose many good qualities will be sadly missed by relatives and friends. She leaves a devoted husband and seven children: Mrs. Charles (Lusetta) SULSBERGER of Climbing Hill, Iowa; Mrs. P. W. (Matilda) GERTLER, of Ozark; Mrs. Henry (Christina) SIEGEL, of Sewickly, Pa.; Mrs. Oscar S. ( Anna) FREITAG, Mrs. Sylvester S. (Ella) BRUBACH, George, and William REICH of Woodsfield; also three brothers, Justus and Adolph CLAUS, of Miltonsburg and Fred CLAUS, of Monroefield, all of whom were in attendance at the funeral except Mrs. Sulsberger  who on account of her husband’s illness was unable to make the trip home. The funeral took place Monday afternoon, the services being conducted at the home by her pastor, the Reverend MEISENHEIMER. Interment in the family lot in Oak Lawn cemetery, Woodsfield.

Name: Louise Catherine KESTNER
Source: Monroe county death records
            Louise Catherine Kestner died February 23, 1920, in Columbus, Ohio. She was born in Monroe county, Ohio September 15, 1866, the daughter of Gottlieb and Louise GERTLER KESTNER. Spouse Albert Ephram MOORE, married February 10, 1888.
 
1920
MARRIAGE
Names:   Mr. Ronald O. HOLMAN
and           Miss Freda L. YOHO
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Mar. 4, 1920
            Miss Freda L. YOHO, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester YOHO, west of town and Mr. Ronald O. HOLMAN, of St. Clairsville, Ohio were united in the holy bonds of matrimony at the M. E. Parsonage in this place Wednesday afternoon, February 25, 1920, by the Rev. George L. DAVIS, in the presence of only a few near relatives and friends.
            They will begin housekeeping at Crestline, Ohio, where the groom has secured employment with the Pennsylvania Railroad Company.
            Both are highly respected young people and have the best wishes of many friends for a long and happy married life.

DEATH
Name:    George KNOPF
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Mar. 25, 1920
            George KNOPF well and favorably known citizen of Brister Station, Ohio, died of heart trouble Wednesday, March 17, 1920, aged 52 years. He was born March 22, 1868, in Monroe county, Ohio, the son of Friederich and Barbara BOTT KNOPF, leaves a wife, Alice BRISTER, and four children. Funeral services were conducted by the Reverend P. W. MEISENHEIMER. Interment in Bracken Chapel cemetery.

Wood, Lucy
d: Mar. 17, 1920
 
1920   XXXXX
DEATH
Name:    Alexander McCAMMON
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, April 1, 1920
            Alexander McCAMMON one of Monroe county’s most highly respected citizens, died at his home northwest of Woodsfield Friday, March 26, 1920, at noon, after a long illness incident to old age.
            Mr. McCammon was born at Wheeling, West Virginia, September 6, 1931, and was 88 years, 6 months and 20 days of age when he died. He was married to Jane McDONALD on October 16, 1862, who preceded him to the Better Land two years ago last December. To this union three sons and two daughters were born. Two sons and two daughters with their families are left to mourn his going, one son having passed to his reward on November 6, 1892.
            Mr. McCammon united with the Buchanan Presbyterian church when a young man, and was a loyal and faithful member until the day of his death.
            Funeral services were conducted by his pastor, the Reverend P. D. LASELLES, on Sunday afternoon at the Buchanan Presbyterian church. Interment in the Buchanan cemetery.
 
1920
Sloan, Peter
d: Mar. 29, 1920
 
1920
DEATH
Name:     Elizabeth CARTER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, April 1, 1920
            Relatives of this place have received an announcement of the death of Mrs. Elizabeth J. CARTER, which occurred at her home at Fayette, Pa., the latter part of last February. Mrs. Carter was a sister to Jerre JACKSON, of this place, was a native of this county, born near Woodsfield March 8, 1840, was married to Samuel CARTER in 1858, but her husband preceded her in death many years ago. Three sons were born to this union, and two are still living She leaves two brothers and one sister: Brice JACKSON, of Chariton, Iowa; Sarah JACKSON, of Washington county, Pa., and Jerre JACKSON, of Woodsfield. These and other relatives have the sincere sympathy of many friends.
 
1920
DEATH
Name:    Dr. C. H. DEVORE
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, April 1, 1920
            Dr. Charles H. DEVORE, one of Woodsfield’s leading citizens and business men died at the Ohio Valley Hospital in Wheeling last Thursday morning, March 25, 1920, of blood poisoning, following several days after a surgical operation in which one foot was amputated. The remains were brought to his home here last Friday at noon. Funeral services were conducted by Dr. George Leslie DAVIS, pastor of the M. E. church, after which the remains were laid to rest in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.
            Dr. Devore was born at Graysville, Ohio, and was 46 years of age. He was a son of John Wesley and Mary Jane DEVORE, and a brother to General D. B. DEVORE, of Chicago; Colonel J. H. DEVORE, of Battle Creek, Michigan; Mrs. Edwards WINCHELL of Mountain Lake Park, Maryland, and Samuel DEVORE, of Wheeling, West Virginia, all of whom were present at the funeral except the father, who has been dead for many years.
            Dr. Devore came to Woodsfield about 30 years ago, and ranked as one of Monroe County’s best dental surgeons. He was married to Miss Edna MALLORY, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. E. MALLORY, on December 18, 1901. To this union were born two children - Miss Maxine and Master WINCHELL DEVORE - who with the mother survive.
            Dr. Devore was a member of the Methodist Episcopal church and Fraternal Order of Eagles. The floral offerings were numerous and beautiful, emblematic of the high esteem in which he was held.
 
1920
Hill, James A.
d: Apr. 10, 1920
1920
Hupp, Sarah A.
d: Apr. 11, 1920
 
1920
DEATH
Name:   Valentine SINGER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, April 8, 1920
            Valentine SINGER, an aged resident of near Woodsfield, who was a victim of a stroke of paralysis while on his way home from church last Sunday morning, died Thursday evening. Funeral services were held at the Catholic church Saturday morning, conducted by the Reverend Father SEEBER, and interment made in the Catholic cemetery.

George Baker
d-April 8, 1920
 
1920XXXXX
DEATH
Name:    Harry BUCKIO
Source:  Monroe County death records
and         The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio Thurs., April 15, 1920
            Harry BUCKIO, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fritz BUCKIO, died Friday morning, April 9, 1920, at the family home on Eastern Avenue after an extended illness, aged 27 years and 16 days.
            He was operated on at Mt. Carmel Hospital, Columbus, Ohio, last August for empyenia, caused by the flu and pneumonia, while serving his country in France, from which he never recovered until death released him from his suffering.
            Harry left Wheeling for Camp Lee in September 1917, and after a few months training left January 17, 1917, for overseas duties, where he served his country for 16 months and was discharged from the service on July 8, 1919.
            He is survived by his parents, three brothers, Charles BUCKIO, of Akron, Ohio; Frank BUCKIO, of Price, Utah, and George BUCKIO, of Oklahoma; one sister, Mrs. Charles HAEFELE, of Cleveland, Ohio, besides numerous other relatives and friends.
            Funeral services were held at the home Monday afternoon at 3:00 o’clock, conducted by the Reverend George L. DAVIS, pastor of the M. E. Church, and by members of the K. of P. organization at the cemetery, of which the deceased was a member. Members of the American Legion acted as pall bearers. Interment was made in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio.
            Mr. Buckio was one of Woodsfield’s most popular and highly respected young men, and by his kind and pleasant disposition, gained legions of friends, whose sympathy is extended to the bereaved ones.
            Many and beautiful were the floral offerings which attested the high esteem in which the deceased was held.
            Seven friends from Wheeling, West Virginia, who were employed in Brown Brothers tailor shop where the deceased was employed for five years, where here Sunday to view the remains and pay a final tribute of respect to one who had been their friend and an inspiration to them in all that was good.
            Near relatives in attendance at the funeral from a distance were his brother Frank BUCKIO, wife and children, of Price, Utah; his sister, Mrs. C. E. HAEFELE, and 2 children, of Cleveland; his brother Charles BUCKIO, and wife and son, of Akron, and his uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. George WISENER, and two sons, of Wheeling. 
 
1920XXXXX
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Birdie Florence AGEY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., April 15, 1920
            Mrs. Birdie Florence AGEY, aged 42 years, wife of Charles AGEY, of Irrville, Ohio, died at the Good Samaritan Hospital, Zanesville, Ohio, at 1 a.m. Saturday morning, April 10, 1920, following an operation for complication of diseases. She was admitted to the hospital on March 26th. Mrs. Agey was a member of the M. E. Church, a member of the Eastern Stars and a worker in the W. C. T. U. She leaves her husband, three children, Crystal Illores, Chester Glenn and Wilford Lloyd AGEY, all of the home, and her mother, Mrs. Margaret MANN, of this place. The remains were brought Monday  noon to the home of her mother on North Main Street, where funeral services were held Tuesday, conducted by the Reverend George L. DAVIS, pastor of the M. E. Church, and interment was made in the Ozark cemetery. The family has the sympathy of the entire community in their bereavement. 
 
1920
Jermone E. Baker
d- April 12, 1920
 
1920
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Rachel HENTHORN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Apr. 22, 1920
            Mrs. Rachel HENTHORN (nee CLEGG) of Cameron, Ohio, was born October 23, 1824, and died April 15, 1920, being at the time of her death 95 years, 5 months and 22 days old.
            On November 5, 1843, she was united in marriage with Jesse B. HENTHORN who preceded her to the Great Beyond February 5, 1908.
            To this union were born seven children, three of whom, Clifford and Thomas HENTHORN of the home and Mrs. George PRYOR of Belaire, Ohio, preceded her to the grave several years ago.
            She leaves to mourn her departure 2 sons, David HENTHORN of Cleveland,  and John HENTHORN of Cambridge, Idaho and two daughters Mrs. Cecelia JONES and Mrs. Sarah KELLER, both of Cameron, Ohio; also 24 grandchildren and a host of relatives and friends.
            She obeyed the gospel at the age of 24, thereby becoming a member of the Church of Christ, of which she was ever a constant and devout worker, ever faithful to Him that doeth all things well.
            She was always found at her post of duty as long as health would permit, her mind being active and alert until her last illness.
            She was ever-ready to minister to the sick and distressed, and her presence will be sadly missed in the little village in which she lived, where she was addressed by almost everyone with the endearing term of “Grandma” Henthorn.
            The funeral services were conducted by Rev. D. Wayne HARKINS of Woodsfield on Friday, April 16, and interment was made in the Old Cemetery by the side of her husband there to await the resurrection morn when they that are in their graves shall hear the voices of the son of God and come forth.
                                               EARL S. WARD
1920
DEATH
Name:     Mrs. C. LUDEY, nee, HEADLEY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., April 29, 1920
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
            Emma A. LUDEY, wife of Ex-Sheriff C. LUDEY, whose death was mentioned in this paper last week, died April 18, 1920, at the Ludey home on North Main street, of a complication of diseases from which she had suffered for a number of years, aged 66 years, 5 months and 25 days. She had received the best of medical treatment and careful nursing, which afforded comfort if not final recovery.
            Mrs. Ludey was a daughter of Hon. Elicl and Rebekah HEADLEY, and was the last living member of that very estimable family. She was born at Cameron, Ohio, and spent the greater part of her life as a citizen of Monroe county, ever ready to do her full duty as a wife and mother, neighbor and friend. She leaves a devoted husband, Chris. LUDEY, of Woodsfield, and two children, Attorney Charles A. LUDEY, of Marietta, and Mrs. Freda R. DENNIS, of Pittsburgh, all of whom were present at the obsequies.
            The funeral took place Wednesday afternoon, April 21st, and the remains were laid to rest in the family lot in Oaklawn cemetery, after well attended services at the home, conducted by the Reverend P. W. MEISENHEIMER. The floral offerings and sympathy extended were but mute evidence of the high esteem in which Mrs. Ludey was held by all who knew her.
 
1920
Louisa Bauer
d-April 19, 1920
1920   XXXXX
DEATH
Name:    Sarah J. OKEY, nee MORRIS
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., April 29, 1920
            The family of R. W. POPE of this place received a telegram last Thursday, announcing the death of Mrs. Sarah J. OKEY, widow of Charles OKEY, which occurred at her home in Corning, Iowa, on April 21, from a stroke of paralysis.
            Mrs. Okey was a daughter of the Honorable James R. MORRIS, founder of The Spirit of Democracy, and spent her early life in Woodsfield, where she will be better remembered as “Sister Morris.” Her husband, Charles OKEY, died several years ago. She had many friends here, where she was universally respected and highly esteemed.

DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Lucinda BUCHANAN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., May 13, 1920
            Mrs. Lucinda BUCHANAN, widow of McClellan BUCHANAN and mother of Mrs. E. C. YOHO of this place, died suddenly at her home in Lewisville, Ohio last Monday evening, May 10, 1920. She had a stroke of paralysis Saturday evening but lingered until about 8:00 o’clock Monday evening. She is survived by 5 daughters, Miss Clara BUCHANAN at home; Mrs. M. M. FISHER and Mrs. W. C. POLEN, of Buchanan Station; Mrs. C. W. YOUNG, of Lewisville, and Mrs. E. C. YOHO, of Woodsfield, besides other relatives and many friends. Mrs. Buchanan was a lady of many good qualities. The funeral will take place this (Wednesday) afternoon. Interment by the side of her husband in Buchanan cemetery after services held at the home by the Reverend P. D. LASELLES.

Source: Newspaper clipping, May 1920
Collection of Beryl Christman Claus
            Mrs. Catherine CHRISTMAN PFALZGRAF died at her home near Altitude Monday, May 19th - just who served two terms as commissioner, of Monroe County, passed to the great beyond. A very highly respected citizen. We have no further particulars at present except that the funeral will take place today (Thursday), and the remains will be laid to rest beside her husband.

d: June 14, 1920
 
1920XXXXX
DEATH
Name:     Anthony BURKHART
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., June 24, 1920
            Another useful and highly respected citizen of Monroe county, in the person of Anthony BURKHART, died at his home near Burkhart Station, Ohio on Wednesday, June 16, 1920, aged 90 years and 4 months to the day.
            Born of a good family in Rhenish Bavaria Bruchweiler, Germany, on the 16th day of February 1830. He came to America in 1851. When 21 years of age, adopted Summit township, Monroe county, Ohio, as his home, where he spent the remainder of his days as a citizen ever faithful to his family, his church and the best interests of the community in which he lived.
            Three years after landing in this country he was married to Miss Hannah KUHN, daughter of Peter KUHN, on September 25, 1854. To this happy union fourteen children were born, all of whom became citizens of sterling character; one son, Peter KUHN, who died about twelve years ago. He leaves to mourn his death an aged wife and ever faithful companion, four daughters and nine sons, as follows: John BURKHART, of Temperanceville, Ohio; Mrs. Mary A. WEISEND, Mrs. Barbara T. WEISEND, Jacob J. and Nicholas BURKHART, of Kuhn, Ohio; Mrs. John HAREN, of Ozark, Ohio; Simon BURKHART and Mrs. Jacob BURKHART, Miltonsburg, Ohio; Anton P. and George A. BURKHART, of Marr, Ohio; Adam J., Joseph W. and Aloysius BURKHART at home with their mother. In addition to this unusually large family of children, 67 grandchildren were born to Mr. and Mrs. Burkhart, 14 of whom have died leaving 53 still living; also 55 great grandchildren, 45 of whom are still living, 10 having died early in life.
            Anthony BURKHART was a devoted member of the Roman catholic church, a loving husband, faithful father and highly respected citizen who will be sadly missed by the many who knew and honored him.
            Well attended funeral services were conducted at St. Joseph’s R. C. church by the Reverend Father IGLE on Friday, June 18. Interment in Chapel Hill cemetery.
            Faithful husband, father and citizen, rest in peace.
 
1920
Carpenter, Delose
d: June 17, 1920
1920
Carpenter, Jane
d: June 18, 1920
 
1920
DEATH
Name:     Nicholas ROTH
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, July 1, 1920
            Nicholas ROTH, a highly respected citizen, of Oak, Ohio, died very suddenly Thursday morning, June 24, 1920.
            Mr. Roth had gone as usual to the barn and cow sheds apparently in usual health. He had cleaned the stables and then must have dropped dead as he reached for buckets to help with the milking. He was not found until some moments later when his son-in-law, Charles SMITH, who was milking noticed his unusual absence and went in search of him.
            Mr. Roth was about 68 years old and had suffered some from heart trouble, which it is thought caused his death.
            The funeral took place Sunday, was largely attended by friends from far and near. Interment at St. Jacob’s German Evangelical cemetery.
 
1920
Carpenter, Delose
d: June 17, 1920
1920
Carpenter, Jane
d: June 18, 1920
1920
Huffman, Sarah A.
d: June 28, 1920

d: July. 14, 1920
1920
Moyer, Frances M.
d: July 30, 1920
 
1920
MARRIAGE
Names:   Mr. Elwin DeWitt FOGLE
and           Miss Isa WILEY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., July 15, 1920
            One of the really happy weddings of the season - elegant and refined in every respect - occurred at the home of Mr. and Mrs. W. F. WILEY, of Jerusalem, Ohio when their charming young daughter, Miss Isa WILEY, was united in marriage with Mr. Elwin DeWITT FOGLE, of Woodsfield, on Wednesday, June 30, 1920, in the presence of near relatives and friends.
            The wedding ceremony was performed by George Leslie DAVIS, pastor of the Woodsfield M. E. church, after which an elegant wedding dinner was served.
            The bride is also a sister of Mrs. Fred SCHUMACHER, of Woodsfield, and a young lady of many good qualities. The groom is a son of County Surveyor C. I. FOGLE and wife of Woodsfield and has a good position as clerk in the post office at this place.
            Mr. and Mrs. Fogle have returned from a wedding trip and are “at home” to their friends on High street where they have gone to housekeeping. The Spirit joins a multitude of friends in wishing them a long and happy married life.
1920
Haught, David S.

1920
DEATH
Name:    W. C. DUFFIELD
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Aug. 26, 1920
            W. C. DUFFIELD, a brother of Mrs. E. W. ARMSTRONG, of this place died at this home in Erie, Pennsylvania, on August 12, 1920. Mr. Duffield was a jeweler and leader in all that was progressive and uplifting. For many years he had been a Sunday school worker and taught one class for 40 years. Those of our acquaintance who attended the funeral were Mrs. E. W. ARMSTRONG and son, James of this place and James and Lucy DUFFIELD of Wheeling.
           
1920

1920
MARRIAGE
Names:   Mr.  Clement L. DRIGGS
and           Mrs. Mary Viola MULLICAN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 23, 1920
            A quiet wedding of more than ordinary interest took place at the home of Mr. and Mrs. James T. DENBOW,  corner of Sycamore and Court streets Sunday morning, at 7:30, when the hand of their daughter, Mrs. Mary Viola MULLICAN, was given in marriage to Mr. Clement L. DRIGGS of South Main street.
            The wedding ceremony was performed by the Reverend J. J. STRODES, pastor of the Presbyterian church.
            Following the ceremony and splendid wedding breakfast the bride and groom left on an extended wedding trip to Atlantic City and other points of interest, and will be “at home” to their friends about November 25.
            They have the best wishes of many friends.

1920
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Mary A. HUFFMAN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Oct. 7, 1920
            Mrs. Mary A. HUFFMAN, widow of Matthias HUFFMAN, died at her home in Antioch Friday, October 1st, aged 86 years and 6 months. She was a fine Christian lady and had been a member of the M. E. church for 72 years. The funeral took place Sunday and was largely attended. The services were conducted by the Reverend D. A. MORGAN, and the remains laid to rest in the Antioch cemetery.
 
1920
Gertler, Louise
d: Oct. 4, 1920
1920
Lude, Lewis J.
d: Oct. 4, 1920
 
1920
George Washington Hines
 
George W. Hines was born Oct 20, 1842, not far from Stafford, on the farm where he spent his entire life.  He died on Oct. 6, 1920, at the age of 71 years, 11 months and 7 days.  He was a son of Joseph and Esther Hines and grew to manhood on the farm.
 
On May 18, 1865, he was married to Miss Lydia Ann Givens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wm. Givens, of Perry two, this county.  To this union a family of five sons and two daughters was born, two of whom – Wier, aged 11 months, and Birdie, aged 3 months – preceded their parents to “rest.”  The surviving children are, Joseph A., of Woodsfield; William Henry, of Summerfield; Thomas R. and Nahum L., of near Sycamore Valley and Mrs. Clara Iva Cronin, who is now at San Antonio, Texas.
 
Mrs. Hines died March 15, 1879 and Mr. Hines was married a second time to Mrs. Sarah C. Craig.  One child, now Mrs. Jennie Longfellow, of near Sycamore Valley, was born to this union.
 
In 1879 Mr. Hines was received into the fellowship of the Church of Christ at Hartshorn and when the church at Clear Frok was organized, he was selected as one of the elders, which position he held at the time of his death.  The house in which the congregation meets for worship is situated on his farm and was purchased by him from a Baptist association.
 
Friendly and hospitable by nature, positive and firm in his convictions, Mr. Hines made his personality a force in his neighborhood, and in his death the community loses a stalwart, honorable and highly respected Christian citizen.  He was a farmer all his life, and his application and ability made him a successful one.
 
Besides the relatives above mentioned he is survived by his widow an aged brother, Woodman Hines, of Stafford; twenty-three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, and many other relatives and friends.
 
Funeral services were held on Thursday afternoon at the Hines meeting house, conducted by Frank Lindewood, of Chandlersville, assisted by elders Geo. B. McFadden and C. L. Millott.  Interment in the Hines cemetery.  A large number of people paid their last tribute of respect to the memory of their aged neighbor and friend.
 
1920
MARRIAGE
Names:   Mr. John KERR
and           Miss Ora HAWKINS
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Oct. 21, 1920
            Miss Ora HAWKINS, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Forrest HAWKINS and Mr. John KERR, son of Mrs. Louise KERR, were united in marriage Wednesday afternoon at the home of the bride on South Main street by Dr. G. L. DAVIS, pastor of the Methodist church, in the presence of a few immediate relatives and friends. Misses Hazel HAUDENSCHIELD and Lelah PRICE acted as bridesmaids and Mr. Roscoe THORNBERRY as best man. After congratulations the guests were taken to the dining room where an elegant wedding dinner was served, after which the young couple left for Gary, Indiana where they will visit relatives. Both are highly respected young people and a host of friends will hasten to extend congratulations.

MARRIAGE
Names:    Mr. Henry BREIDING
and            Miss Augusta BURKHART
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Nov. 4, 1920
            On Tuesday morning, October 5, 1920, occurred the wedding at the R. C. church at Ozark of Miss Augusta BURKHART, daughter of Mrs. Anthony BURKHART of Ozark, Ohio, to Mr. Henry BREIDING, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph BREIDING of Akron, Ohio. The attendants were Miss Nellie BURKHART, sister of the bride of this place, and Mr. Leonard BREIDING, brother of the groom, of Cincinnati. After the ceremony they repaired to the home of the bride’s mother, where a sumptuous dinner was served to them and quite a number of near relatives. In the evening a dance was given in their honor at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Otto BURKHART at which place they were also given a big serenade. They received many and beautiful presents. They left the next morning for Akron in Mr. Breiding’s car, where they are to have a reception at the home of the groom’s parents. They will reside in Akron.                           A SISTER

            These highly respected young people have the best wishes of many friends.
