1920
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Virginia A. NOLL
Source: Hannibal Correspondent
Hannibal, Ohio, November 15, 1920
            Mrs. Virginia A. NOLL aged 72 years, wife of John NOLL and a very highly esteemed woman, died at her home on Tuesday morning, November 2, 1920, after an illness of several months from dropsy. Besides her husband, the deceased is survived by four children: Mrs. Fred NOLL of Greensburgh, Pa.; Robert NOLL of Marietta; Mark and Orville NOLL of this place, and by nine grandchildren and many other relatives. The funeral was held on Thursday afternoon and the services were conducted at her late home by her pastor, Reverend C. F. WALTERS of the M. E. church, of which the deceased was a member, and interment was in the Emma Grove cemetery. There were many beautiful floral offerings.
            Relatives from a distance attending the funeral were Logan NOLL and daughter and Mrs. Rolland HARLEY of Marietta; Mr. and Mrs. M. F. NOLL of Cincinnati; Mrs. Wilbert WOODS of Martins Ferry; Mrs. Harry CONRAD, Mrs. W. HOUSE and Mrs. Harvey BERNARD of Wheeling.
1920XXXXX
DEATH
Name:   Private Ignatius C. BIEDENBACH
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Nov. 25, 1920
            The remains of Private Ignatius C. BIEDENBACH, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles BIEDENBACH, of Kuhn, Ohio, who died of pneumonia in Germany on February 4, 1919, arrived in Woodsfield and were taken to the Bauer & Willison undertaking parlors. The funeral was held Wednesday of last week by the Reverend Theodore IGEL, pastor of the R. C. church at Burkhart, after which the remains were laid to rest with full military honors in the R. C. cemetery at Chapel Hill. This brave young lad, who paid the supreme sacrifice leaves a father, mother, two sisters, four brothers and many friends.
 
1920
Knapp, Purlina
d: Nov. 25, 1920
1920
Schmidt, John
d: Nov. 27, 1920
 
1920
DEATH
Name:    Willard LeMoyne WOHNHAS
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Nov. 25, 1920
            Willard LeMoyne WOHNHAS, second youngest son of Charles E. and Mary Alice WOHNHAS, was born on July 10, 1906, and died November 3, 1920, being at the time of his death 14 years, 3 months and 23 days old.
            He leaves in his family a father, three sisters and three brothers. His mother preceded him to the Great Beyond March 20, 1913.
            Willard will be missed in the school room, the family circle, and oh! so sadly missed in the home, but we sorrow not as those who have no hope. Our imaginations are not so deep as to conceive why one so young in years and so closely attached to us should be separated from us and while forbidden to murmur we are not forbidden to regret and his kindness and cheerfulness reflects to our memories and each past deed is cherished in our hearts to be pursued with affectionate remembrance.
            The funeral services were conducted by Evangelist C. H. MORIN on Saturday afternoon at the West Union church after which the remains followed by a large concourse of sorrowing relatives and friends, were laid to rest beside those of his mother to await the Resurrection morn.
When blooming youth is snatched away
By death’s resist less hand,
Our hearts the mournful tribute pay
Which pity must demand.
 
1920
MARRIAGE
Names:  Mr. J. C. NAUER
and          Miss Jesse BULGER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Dec. 2, 1920
            Miss Jesse BULGER and Mr. J. C. NAUER of this place were quietly married at Wheeling, West Virginia last Saturday and have been congratulated by a large number of friends. The bride is an accomplished young daughter of Mrs. Mary FERGUSON, of this place and popular in society circles. The groom is a Conductor on the O. R & W. railway and a young man of many good qualities.

1920
DEATH
Name:   Miss Hattie FULTON
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Dec. 2, 1920
            On Friday, November 19, 1920, that silent messenger, the angel of death, saw it to visit our home and took from our midst the beloved daughter, Hattie, of Mr. and Mrs. Emery FULTON of Altitude, Ohio. She was born March 10, 1891, being at the time of her death 29 years, 8 months and 9 days old. About the age of 15 years she became a member of the United Presbyterian church at Pleasant Ridge. She was a faithful member until God saw fit to call her spirit home. She spent the last five years in Cleveland, and in January she was stricken with flu and pneumonia which later developed into tuberculosis. For four months she was cared for at her sister’s and in May she was able to be brought to her home where she longed to be, thinking the change would be a benefit to her, but she gradually grew worse and all that medical skill and loving hands could do were done for sickness with patience, without a murmur of complaint. She had a kind disposition and was loved and respected by all who knew her. As the end drew near she called for Jesus, dear Jesus, to come and take me away. For Thou hasn’t been so precious to me. She leaves to mourn her departure a father and mother, five sisters, and one brother, namely, Mrs. T. E. TRUEX, Wellsville, Ohio; Mrs. I. L. SCHUMACHER, Woodsfield; Mrs. F. F. RUFF, Cleveland, Inez and Florence FULTON, at home, and Forrest FULTON, at Wellsville, besides a host of relatives and friends.
            Funeral services were held Monday in the Presbyterian church at Woodsfield, conducted by the Reverend BROWNLEE and assisted by the Reverend SRODES. She was laid to rest in the Oaklawn cemetery to await the resurrection morn.
We miss thee from our home dear Hattie,
We miss thee from thy place;
A shadow o’er our life is cast,
We miss the sunshine of your face.
Through cast down, we’re not forsaken,
Though afflicted not alone;
Thou gave and Thou hath taken,
Blessed Lord thy will be done.
 
1920
MARRIAGE
Names:    Mr. T. O. DICKEY
and            Miss Clara WALT
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Dec. 9, 1920
            A wedding of more than ordinary interest took place at Columbus, Ohio, on November 24, 1920, when Mr. T. O. DICKEY, of Woodsfield, and Miss Clara WALT of Columbus were untied in marriage. The bride is a charming young daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William WALT of the Capital city and a graduate of the North High School of Columbus. Mr. Dickey, son of Mrs. William DICKEY of Jerusalem, Ohio is a graduate of Ohio State University and teacher of Agriculture in the Woodsfield public schools. They will reside in Woodsfield and have been given a cordial welcome.

1920
DEATH
Name:  Charles G. OBLINGER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. Dec. 16, 1920
            Charles G. OBLINGER, one of Monroe county’s oldest and most highly respected citizens, died at his home in Lewisville, Ohio, Friday, December 10, 1920, following an operation for double hernia. The news of his death came as a shock to the many who knew and respected him above men of the ordinary class. The public in general had not been apprised of his ailments.
            The funeral took place from the home last Monday at 2:00 p.m. and was largely attended by relatives and friends from far and near. The religious services were conducted by Rev. CHASSER, of Belle Valley, assisted by Rev. P. W. MEISENHEIMER. Interment in the Lewisville cemetery.
            C. G. OBLINGER was a brother to Mrs. Louis HOEFFLER of this place and a brother of the late Ottillia WAY.
            Mr. Oblinger was 72 years, eight months and 22 days old at the time of his death. He entered the mercantile business at Lewisville about 51 years ago and spent the remainder of his life in serving a large number of patrons in that vicinity, all of whom will continue to respect him as a friend of many good qualities. Always thoughtful of the poor and the deserving he will long be remembered as a philanthropist of the higher order.
            Quiet a number of Woodsfield relatives and friends attended the funeral.
            A noble friend, requiescat in pace.
 
1920XXXXXs
DEATH
Name:   George W. BRACY
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Dec. 16, 1920
            George BRACY died at the Good Samaritan Hospital at Zanesville, Ohio Sunday morning December 5, 1920.
            Several weeks ago he received injuries in a fall while in Akron his head striking the pavement. Concussion of the brain resulted. He came home and his condition appeared favorable but gradually grew worse and recently he was taken to the hospital in hopes of relief from an operation expert medical advice counseled against this as meningitis had developed.
            Mr. Bracy was born near Woodsfield July 28, 1857, and was a son of Mr. and Mrs. John BRACY. He was married August 1, 1877, to Miss Izora WILLIS and they spent their entire married life in or near Woodsfield. A family of six children was born to them -  all of whom are living except one son Forrest -  who died some years ago.
            Besides his widow the surviving children are Mrs. Wm. WINLAND; John BRACY; Mrs. L. S. ALBEE; Mrs. C. E. KING of Woodsfield; Mrs. Mary SKOLMUTCH of Massillon and Miss Sadie BRACY at home. One brother A. S. BRACY of Cleveland also survives him as does also one sister Mrs. Sarah McGAUGHEY of Akron, Ohio.
            Funeral services were held at the residence Tuesday afternoon December 7 and were conducted by Elder J. A. HINES of the Church of Christ of which the deceased was a member.
            Mr. Bracy was a goodhearted and industrious citizen and was known personally to almost every resident of Woodsfield. His even-tempered and kindly disposition made him many friends and his death is keenly felt not only by his family but by scores of people who knew him well.
 
1920
Marial L. Brown

1921   XXXXX
DEATH
Name:  Thomas J. MORRIS
Provided by Betty (Latta) Kitchen
 THOMAS JEFFERSON MORRIS (13 July 1845 - 1921)
            The Morris family Bible lists his birthday as July l3, 1845.
            He lived on a farm over the hill from the Latta homestead.  His  children went to Fox Hollow School.  Some of them are on the picture I have of the class of 1893.  Pictured there are Dolph, Lydia, Belle, Grover and John Morris.    He is not mentioned in the 1880 Federal Census of Monroe County.   Perhaps he had moved because the children of him and his second wife Susanna were born from 1881 through 1890.
        Tom Morris was the last one buried on the plot on the Latta farm in Monroe County.  The family had to get special permission to do it.  Don and I visited this cemetery in 2002.  His stone was about 12 feet from the main line of the rest of the family.  About 10 x 14 inches showed above the ground.  It was still standing.  Each of the engraved lines was centered.
 T.J.
 MORRIS
 1845-1921
            The records regarding his children were given to Elsie by the grandchildren of Thomas J. Morris of the second marriage to Susannah.  They gave William Morris as a son of this marriage.  [She questioned whether he should be entered there or as a son of the first marriage since he was born in January, 1879, and Thomas J. and the second wife were not married until July 7, 1879.  I entered him with the first wife until we find her date of death.  Perhaps she died in childbirth.]
            We have a copy of his certificate of death.  The informant was his son Alva Morris who did not know the birthplace of Thomas J.'s father or mother (Henry or Mary Kinkade Morris).  The cause of death was gastro enteris catarrh.  It said the disease was contracted "at home."
 
1921
Diehl, Catherine
d: Jan. 7, 1921
 
1921
DEATH
Name:     Mrs. Catherine DIEHL
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 13, 1921
            Mrs. Catherine DIEHL aged 82 years, died at the family home on South Main street Friday morning at four o’clock after an illness of pneumonia. Mrs. Diehl is the widow of Wm. DIEHL, who died twenty years ago. She was the mother of twelve children, seven living, three girls and four boys as follows: Mrs. Sophia BERTRAM, Mrs. A. G. CHRISTMAN, Mrs. Louise SULSBERGER, J. W. and F. E. DIEHL, all of Woodsfield; George DIEHL of Memphis, Tenn., and Fred M. DIEHL of Grand Junction, Colorado. She is also survived by an adopted son, Wm. BRUBACH of Chicago, whose mother died when about two months old; one brother, John NEUHART of West Virginia, and one sister, Mrs. Conrad DIEHL of Clinton, Missouri. Funeral services were held at the home Monday at two o’clock conducted by her pastor, Rev. J. J. SRODES, pastor of the Presbyterian church, and interment in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio.

1921
DEATH
Name:    Mr. Harry O. GOODRICH
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Mar. 31, 1921
            Brief announcements of the sudden death of Mr. Harry O. GOODRICH, former editor and proprietor of The Monroe Courier, and eldest son of Charles H. GOODRICH, well known at one time as editor of The Monroe Gazette. Harry, it seems had been in poor health for some time. He had been working on a paper near his home at Hot Springs, Arkansas, with his son, James GOODRICH. He became worse and his son started home to Hot Springs with him, but he died of apoplexy on the train. His remains were taken to Nashville, Tennessee for burial, where most of his children lived. His death occurred March 16, 1921. He leaves a wife and several children.

1921
DEATH
Name:   Henry DOUGHERTY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs. Apr. 28, 1921
            Sergeant Henry DOUGHERTY of Woodsfield, one of Monroe County’s most highly respected Civil war veterans, died at his home in Woodsfield Monday morning, April 25, 1921, at 8:20 after a short illness from heart trouble, aged 78 years, 5 months and 7 days of age.
            Sergeant Dougherty was not only a citizen of many good qualities, ever sanctioning the right and doing all in his power for the betterment of mankind and those about, but was a soldier of the Civil war and a savior of American integrity with a was record of more than three years which for meritorious work and achievement was surpassed by few if any.
            He enlisted under the stars and stripes, October 5, 1861, and was mustered in as a private to serve three years in Company K, 62nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry under Captain William DOUGHERTY, Henry R. WEST and John D. KENNEDY. His regiment left for Cumberland, Maryland on January 17, 1862, and was attached to 2nd Brig. Landers Division, Army of the Potomac in March 1862. With his company he advanced in March 1862, to Winchester, Virginia and from that time on until honorably discharged on October 26, 1864, participated in many of the hardest fought battles of the great was, with a very short hospital record.
            On December 12, 1861, he was promoted from Private Corporal, and on September 10, 1862, he was promoted to Sergeant for gallant and meritorious service on the fields of battle.
            Sergeant Henry DOUGHERTY leaves to mourn him, his wife, three sons, William, Asher and Mahlon DOUGHERTY, of Ashland, Ohio and three daughters, Mrs. W. T. RUFF of this place and Mary and Margaret DOUGHERTY of the home.
            The funeral will take place this Thursday morning, April 28 at 9:30. Interment in the St. Sylvestors Catholic cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio with honors of General W. P. Richardson Grand Army Post. Respected soldier and citizen, rest in peace. 
 
1921
(Stillborn) Burkhart
d-April 29, 1921

Davidson, William

1921XXXXX
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Jacob H. BOTT
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., May 12, 1921
            Mrs. Jacob H. BOTT of Columbus, Ohio, well and favorably known here died at the St. Clair Hospital in Columbus last Saturday evening following an operation for hernia. The remains were brought to Woodsfield Monday evening and taken to the home of her brother-in-law, Louis BOTT on Eastern avenue, where they were viewed by many friends prior to the funeral which took place last Tuesday afternoon.
            Mrs. Bott was a daughter of Godfrey and Catherine CHRISTMAN, and spent her childhood days in this county where she has many friends.
 
1921
DEATH
Name:    Daniel NEUHART
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., May 19, 1921
            Mayor Lewis P. NEUHART of this place received a telegram Thursday of last week announcing the death of his brother, Daniel NEUHART which occurred at his home in Los Angeles, California, on Thursday morning, May 12, 1921. The cause of his death was not stated, but was presumably ailments incident to old age, as he was almost 70 years of age.
            Daniel NEUHART, whom many of the older citizens of Woodsfield will remember  as  a  model  citizen,  was  born in Ruppertsweiler, by Permasens, Rheinpfalz, Germany, on June 24, 1951, and came with his parents, Daniel and Catherine (KESTNER) NEUHART to Monroe county in 1852, when the county was comparatively new.
            Leaving Woodsfield many years ago, Daniel NEUHART, the subject of this sketch, located in Caldwell, Ohio where he conducted a drug store for a number of years, leaving later in life for Los Angeles, California, where he spent the remainder of his life.
            He leaves at this place one daughter, Mrs. Charles BOTT, and a brother - Mayor Lewis P. NEUHART, who have the sincere sympathy of many friends.
 
1921
Yontz, Mary M.
d: May 14, 1921

1921
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Mary A. DOUGHERTY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, June 2, 1921
            The death of Mrs. Mary Ann DOUGHERTY, widow of the late Stephen DOUGHERTY and one of Woodsfield’s most highly respected old ladies of pioneer experience occurred at her home on South Main street last Sunday morning, May 29, 1921. The funeral occurred Wednesday morning June 1st and her remains were laid to rest in St. Sylvester’s R. C. Cemetery. Among those who attended the funeral from a distance were Bernard, Ellsworth, S. O., Richard, Charles, Lawrence HUGHES and their mother, Mrs. R. A. HUGHES, who motored in from Toronto; her son S. O. DOUGHERTY of Toronto; Katherine WILLISON of East Liverpool; Richard DOUGHERTY and Hannah DORR of McKees Rocks, Pa. making five generations of the family represented.
            We hope to be able to give further account of the life and death of this grand lady in the near future.

DEATH
Name:  Wilson Henry MORRIS
 Death Records, Monroe County, Ohio, Vol. 1, Washington Twp.,  
 Collection of Betty Latta Kitchen
 William H. Morris
 date of death - July 1, 1921
 date of birth - March 20, 1827
 place of birth - Ohio
 cause of death - acute  gastritis
 color - white; sex - male; occupation - farmer
 parents' name - Henry Morris
 by whom reported - R. H. Latta M.D.
            Wilson and some of his children are buried at Merrill Ridge Church Cemetery, near Rinard Mills, Monroe County, Ohio.  Elizabeth Hinton has pictures of the church and stones.
            WILSON HENRY MORRIS (20 Mar 1827 - 1 July 1921)                                                                                                   “Wilson Morris"
            Catharine Fedorchak's Family Research in Monroe Co., Vol. II, Part II:  "In the 1860 census Henry Morris can be found on page 132, Family No. 619.  His three oldest sons are on page 514 in Wayne Township, families 1061 -  Wilson, married to Hannah Jane LONG. . . Also on page 38 of this volume:  "Wilson Morris died in Monroe Co. at the age of 94 and some of his descendants live near Rinard's Mills on Route 26." Elsie Bonam gave me a handwritten receipt signed by Wilson: "August 28th  1860    Received of H. G. Morris three hundred and seventy-five dollars to pay on land. Elsie Bonam's notes:  "Wilson married Hannah Jane Long about 1858.  She died November 16, 1878, at the age of 38 years and 23 days, believed to be the daughter of Jacob Long and Hannah. No marriage record is available of Wilson Morris and Hannah Jane Long because several fires in Monroe County, Ohio."                                Application to Probate Filed: Wilson Morris deceased July 13th. A.D. 1921...................instrument of writing, purporting to be the last Will of          Wilson Morris of Washington              Township, in this County, deceased, was produced in open Court for Probate, and there being no widow it is now  ..........the said Will be filed, and that due notice thereof and of the application to admit the same to Probate and record be given in writing, James MORRIS, Frank MORRIS, Evaline WILLIAMS, Jacob MORRIS, Newton MORRIS and Melissa HALL, and by publication for 3 weeks in the Spirit of Democracy to Thurman MORRIS, Clesson MORRIS, Oral [?] MORRIS and Webster PRATT next of kin of the testator. ^  (except the last family  whose address is unknown .............the State of Ohio five days prior thereto; that said application will be for hearing before this Court, on the 6th day of August A.D. 1921 at 10  A.M. and this cause is continued.                                               O. P. C?assil, Probate Judge"  [or perhaps Gassil?]
            His death record found in Vol. 1, page 98 of Washington Twp., Monroe county, gave this information:  [We have a copy of this record.]
 date of death - July 1, 1921
 date of birth - March 20, 1827
 place of birth - Ohio
 cause of death - acute  gastritis
 color - white; sex - male;
 occupation - farmer
 parents' name - Henry Morris
 by whom reported - R. H. Latta M.D.
            Wilson and some of his children are buried at Merrill Ridge Church Cemetery, near Rinard Mills, Monroe County, Ohio.  Elizabeth Hinton has pictures of the church and stones.
 
1921
DEATH
Name:    Philip L. ULLMAN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, July 7, 1921
            Philip L. ULLMAN, prosperous farmer and stock dealer of Harriettsville, aged 71 years 11 months and 5 days, drowned Wednesday evening about 9:45 in Duck Creek, a quarter of a mile from his home, when the horse he was driving backed the buggy in which he was riding over the bank throwing him out and pinning him beneath its weight. Thus trapped Mr. Ullman lost his life in less than three feet of water. His body was recovered from the stream a short time afterward by persons summoned to the scene by the victim’s wife who was the only witness to the accident.
            Mr. Ullman had been away from home all day buying cattle and looking after other business. When almost home he was met by his wife who was attempting to get him in the rig when the horse began to back. Mr. Ullman was unable to stop the horse and it went over a six-foot embankment near the home of W. A. SCHAFER.
            On January 28, 1875, he was united in marriage to Theresa E. UNGER. To this union eight children were born, two of whom have gone before.
            He is survived by his wife and the following children: Mrs. C. E. JOHANNING of near Harrietsville; Lewis ULLMAN of Harriettsville; Rupert ULLMAN of Lowell; Mrs. J. P. HARTSHORN of Germantown; Mrs. Sam BRAUND of Sebring and Miss Elsie ULLMAN of Washington, D. C., ten grandchildren, two brothers, Daniel and Henry ULLMAN, and a host of relatives and friends.
 
1921
Denver Anderson
d-July 11, 1921
 
1921XXXXX
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Mary L. BAKER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., July 21, 1921
            Mrs. Mary L. BAKER, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Job STACKHOUSE, was born at New Castle, Belmont county, Ohio, June 27, 1846, and departed this life at her home in Antioch, Ohio, July 4, 1921, aged 75 years and 7 days.
            She was united in marriage with Henry L. BAKER January 1, 1867. To this union were born 6 children, three sons and three daughters.
            She leaves to mourn her sad departure, 5 children, Charles C. BAKER, Antioch, Ohio; Lemuel A. BAKER, Wheeling, West Virginia; H. O. BAKER, Columbus, Ohio; Mrs. Nettie WONHNHAS, Sardis, Ohio; Mrs. Edna CRAWFORD, Allison, Iowa; (Carrie L. BAKER, deceased); 24 grandchildren, 3 great grandchildren, one sister, Mrs. WILSON of Barnesville, Ohio; one brother, Mr. STACKHOUSE. Her husband passed away 18 years ago.
            She obeyed the gospel March 24, 1896, under the ministry of Elder Thomas PIATT, and was sound in the faith and a humble Christian. Sister Baker was a good woman, loved by all who knew her.
            Funeral services were conducted by Elder A. CALVERT, assisted by Elder T. P. ULLOM in the Christian church at Antioch, Ohio, after which her body was laid to rest in the Antioch cemetery, there to await the coming of her Lord.
            The dear bereaved ones have the sympathy of the entire community.

and         St. John’s Church records
Lewisville, Ohio, August 20, 1921

1921
 DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Caroline HYER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 1, 1921
            Mrs. Caroline HYER was born April 24, 1835, in Weurtenberg, Germany, and passed away at her home in Hannibal, Ohio, August 19, 1921, aged 86 years, 3 months and 25 days. In her 17th year she came to America and settled in Wheeling, West Virginia. In 1855, she was united in marriage to Godfrey HYER and in 1864 they came to Hannibal, where she has since resided and proved herself a neighbor and friend, and loved by all who knew her. Formerly she was a member of the Evangelical church, but in 1897, she joined the German M. E. church and remained a faithful and active member until her death. Her husband and three children preceded her and the following children survive: Mrs. Carrie NEUENSCHWANDER of Cleveland, John HYER of Akron, Ohio; Henry HYER of Lima, Ohio, and David HYER of Wheeling. The deceased is also survived by 11 grandchildren and 8 great grand children. Her funeral was held on Sunday afternoon and the services were largely attended and were conducted at her late home by her pastor, Rev. E. A. RODAHAFFER, and interment was made in the family lot in the Harter cemetery. There were beautiful offerings.
 
1921
Walters, Arthur
d: Aug. 25, 1921
 
1921
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Susannah SWALLOW
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 8, 1921
            Mrs. Susannah SWALLOW, widow of the late James SWALLOW of Brownsville and mother of County Auditor I. O. SWALLOW, died at her home Saturday morning, September 3rd. She had suffered from a slight stroke of paralysis for several years and took worse Friday night, presumably the result of another stroke, and died Saturday morning aged 88 years. Auditor Swallow and other members of her family were at her bedside at the time. Mrs. Swallow was a pioneer citizen of Monroe county, a consistent member of the M. E. church and a citizen of high moral character beloved by all who knew her. The funeral took place Monday.

1921
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Harry NEUHART
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 8, 1921
            Relatives of this place have been notified of the death of Mrs. Harry NEUHART at her home in Sistersville, Ohio on Saturday, September 3, 1921, following a surgical operation, aged 29 years. She was a daughter-in-law of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. NEUHART, well known former residents of this place, and leaves a husband and three children, the youngest only about one month old. Funeral last Monday.
 
1921
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Dollie NEUHART
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept.  22, 1921
            Mrs. Dollie NEUHART, nee SMITH, well and favorably known at this place, died at her home in Wheeling Friday morning, aged 86 years, following a long illness from ailments incident to old age.
            Mrs. Neuhart was a widow of Chris NEUHART, who departed this life in 1908. She was also the mother of Mrs. Louis P. NEUHART of this place who was at her bedside at the time of her death and on many precious occasions during the past few months.
            Mrs. Dollie NEUHART was born and spent many of the best years of her life in Woodsfield, where she was highly respected by all who knew her. She leaves but one sister, Mrs. LISLE.
            The remains were brought to Woodsfield Monday and remained at the home of her daughter, Mrs. L. P. NEUHART until Tuesday morning, where many of her old-time friends and others called to pay marks of respect to one they had learned to love.
            The funeral, conducted by Rev. Joseph REINICKE, occurred Tuesday morning at 9:00 o’clock when the remains were laid to rest in Oaklawn cemetery, Bauer & Willison, acting as funeral directors.
            The floral offerings numerous and of fine quality, spoke in terms more impressive than we can describe of the high esteem in which she was held.
            May we all live lives that will so be so overly remembered.
            We hope to be able to give further particulars later.
 
1921
Walters, Leonard E.
d: Sept. 19, 1921
 
 
1921
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Barbara SCHUETZ
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 29, 1921
            Mrs. Barbara SCHUETZ, aged 80, a lifelong resident of Monroe county, Ohio died Saturday, Sept. 24, 1921, at 3:30 p.m. at her home on Hope ridge, north of Woodsfield.
            Mrs. Schuetz had been an invalid for some time and early in last August fell out of bed and had a hip and both arms broken.
            Mrs. Schuetz leaves two children, Jacob and Elizabeth SCHUETZ, residing at home. Her husband Adam SCHUETZ, preceded her by many years.
            Funeral services will be held at 10:00 o’clock Tuesday morning from the Evangelical church Miltonsburg. Burial will be at Miltonsburg.

DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Margaret ACKERMAN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Oct. 13, 1921
            Margaret ACKERMAN, estimable wife of Charles ACKERMAN, died at her home on West Marietta street, Woodsfield, at 6:00 o’clock Saturday evening, October 8, 1921, aged 54 years. Mrs. Ackerman was of a cheerful nature and honorable disposition to the extent that she had many friends. She leaves a devoted husband, one daughter, Estella ACKERMAN, and many other relatives and friends. The funeral services, conducted by the Rev. Father SEEBER, took place at the Catholic church last Tuesday morning. Interment in the Catholic cemetery.
 
1921
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Margaret PENN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Oct. 13, 1921
            Mrs. Margaret PENN, one of Woodsfield’s most highly respected octogbenarians, died at her home on South Main street Monday, October 10, 1921, following a recent stroke of paralysis from which she rallied but slightly.
            Mrs. Penn was born May 7, 1841, and was therefore 80 years, 5 months and 3 days old. She formerly resided at Graysville and has many friends wherever known. Her husband, Charles P. PENN, has been dead a number of years.
            The funeral took place this (Wednesday) afternoon with Dr. DAVIS of the M. E. Church in charge of the services.
            Interment in the Connor Ridge cemetery.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Oct. 20, 1921
            Mrs. Anna HIGGINS, wife of Thornton S. HIGGINS of Jackson ridge, died at midnight Sunday. She was 55 years of age. She leaves a husband and one son, Otto of the home. Funeral services were held this (Wednesday) morning at 10 o’clock at Fletcher’s Chapel, near New Castle.

1921
DEATH
Name: Mrs. Anna Wise, nee Kelley
Source: newspaper article, Oct. 1921
Provided by Eloise Lumbatis January
            Once more the angel of death has visited the community of Neffs, Ohio, and taken from its midst a devoted wife and mother, Mrs. Anna Wise, daughter of Sebastian and Susie Kelley. She was born August 4, 1864, near Lewisville, Ohio, and died October 24, 1921, at her home at Neffs, Belmont county, Ohio. She was united in marriage to Peter Wise July 18, 1886. To this union nine children were born: Willie, Carl, Lando, Charles, Estella, Luna, Mary, Esther, and another son who died in infancy.
            She is one who will be sadly missed from her home and friends as her life was one of usefulness and good deeds wherever she was present. At the early age of 14 years she became a member of the M. E. church at Bracken Chapel, Summerfield charge. Later she moved her name to Neffs, where she remained a faithful and consistent member until death. She was a willing worker in the church, Sunday School and W. C. T. U.
            The afternoon preceding her death she spent in visiting her children. At. 6 o’clock in the evening she was suddenly stricken with paralysis. At. 9 o’clock she was cold in death. The record of her life is finished. Not a line need be censored. She has fought a good fight and has gone to her heavenly home where sorrow never comes and we shall never say “Goodbye.”
            She leaves to mourn her loss a husband, eight children, three sisters, Mrs. J. H. Billman of Lewisville, Ohio; Mrs. Vincent Thompson of New Philadelphia, Ohio; Mrs. Joseph Balentine of Holloway, Ohio; one brother J. T. Kelley of Stonecreek, Ohio; two half-sisters, Mrs. Jane Miracle of Summerfield, Ohio; Mrs. S. W. Dooley of Stafford, Ohio, and a wide circle of other relatives and friends. She is preceded to the land beyond by one sister, six years and a brother only four weeks. She is not alone but has gone to meet her loved ones.
            Funeral services wee conducted by her pastor. the remains were laid to rest on October 27, in High Ridge cemetery, Neffs, Ohio. - - Niece.
 
 
1921
MEDIS, John Calvin
 Active members Church of Christ, Paden City, W. VA.
** IN MEMORIAM**
"OBITUARY"
By Ira C. Moore, (old newspaper clipping)
 
MEDIS-John Calvin, was born into this world in Monroe County, Ohio on Oct. 1, 1843, and died at his brother's in Paden City, W. VA., October 24, 1921, being aged 78 years and twenty-three days. At the age of eighteen he was born again under the preaching of the documented and honored Nathan W. Cramblett and according to the testimony of those who knew him, he ever lived a faithful Christian life. His late home was in New Brighton, PA, but recently went on a visit to his native community and conducted the worship only about two weeks before his death. A few years ago he sojourned in Paden City for a time and formed many acquaintances and made a good record by attending the worship there. Fifty years ago he was married to Miss Catherine Richner and to them were born five girls and three boys. He came to Paden City to visit his brother and died there, this writer was called to cover the funeral on Tuesday, October 25. The worn out body of Bro. Medis was laid to rest in the cemetery near to await the judgment day.
*****
"The funeral services were held in a small country church, John C. Medis remains were not brought back to PA. for burial.

1921
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. V. M. BAKER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Nov. 3, 1921
            Mrs. V. M. BAKER (Mary H.) died at her home near Laings, Ohio Sunday about one o’clock. She had been ill for the past two months from an infection in her foot, but recently it seemed danger from that trouble was past.
            Sunday she ate a hearty dinner and seemed unusually cheerful and well, when she suddenly became faint and asked to be taken to her bed, where she died a few minutes later. Her son, John, had just left a few minutes before on his way back to Wheeling, under the impression that his mother was in a fair way toward complete recovery.
            Mrs. Baker leaves a husband, two sons, John BAKER, of Wheeling, Oliver M. BAKER of Akron, and two daughters, Mrs. Adda GILLESPIE of Woodsfield and Mrs. F. S. ESHLEMAN of Casper, Wyoming.
            Funeral services were held Weds., October 26th, at Moffet’s M. E. church.
 
1921
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Louis SPIRY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Nov. 10, 1921
            Ross BUCHANAN of Woodsfield has received a letter announcing the death of his sister, Mrs. Louis SPIRY at her home in Wood county, West Virginia, on October 29, 1921. The funeral took place on October 31st. Mr. and Mrs. Spiry were born and raised to manhood and womanhood near Decker Station and moved to West Virginia many years ago. Deceased whose maiden name was Melissa BUCHANAN, leaves besides her brother Ross and husband Louis, two sons and two daughters. She was about 67 years of age and has many friends in this county who will regret to learn of her death.

DEATH
Name:    Mrs. D. W. SMITH
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Dec. 22, 1921
            Mrs. Sarah SMITH, wife of D. W. SMITH of Woodsfield, who has been in very poor health for several years past, died Friday evening at her home on South Main street, aged 61 years. She was a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James R. ARNOLD of Beallsville, but had been a resident of Woodsfield for may years. She was a member of the M. E.  church and the Eastern Star, and was regarded as one of the best members of each organization. She leaves beside her husband, two sons in Woodsfield, Alfred and Harry SMITH; one daughter, Mrs. W. K. GREENBANK of Wooster and one son, D. Frank SMITH of Marietta, Ohio.
            The funeral took place Sunday afternoon and was largely attended. Interment in Oaklawn cemetery.
 
1921

1922
DEATH
Name:    George GREENBANK
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 12, 1922
            George GREENBANK Senior, a brother to the late Richard and John GREENBANK of Lewisville, died at the Memorial Hospital in Piqua, Ohio, on December 28, 1921. He was also an uncle of Mrs. George WEBER of Oaklawn avenue, A. R. GREENBANK of Lewisville, W. K. GREENBANK of Wooster, and O. M. GREENBANK of this office. The Piqua Daily call in speaking of his death says:        
            Mr. Greenbank of Urbana, Ohio father of Harry E. GREENBANK popular jeweler with A. L. RICHEY, passed away this morning at one o’clock at the memorial hospital. Mr. Greenbank has been in the habit of coming over to Piqua often to see his son and has been taking treatment at the Memorial hospital. About two weeks ago Mr. Greenbank was forced to enter the hospital for treatment and was never able to leave his bed during his last sickness. He was eighty years of age and a veteran of the Civil War. He is survived by his son Harry GREENBANK of this city. The funeral services will be held at Urbana on Friday afternoon with the burial at Oakdale cemetery.

1922
DEATH
Name:   Miss Louise Matilda HETTIG
Source: Monroe County Death records
and         St. John’s Church records
and        Monroe County Republican
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Feb. 23, 1922
Collection of Beryl Christman Claus
            Despondency, brought on by continued ill health, is held responsible for the death by suicide of Louise Matilda HETTIG, aged 24, at her home about 1 1/2 miles north of Lewisville, Ohio, Tuesday evening, February 21, 1922.
            Miss Hettig, according to information from Lewisville, was unwilling to go to a hospital for treatment. It was said that she gave no indication of her intention to members of the family excepting a remark made on Monday, when she asserted that she did not expect to live long. Tuesday evening she was found on a porch by a brother, breathing her last, her throat cut. A butcher knife was close by.
            Owing to the fact that there is no qualified corner in Monroe County, Constable John FEIOCK served, as provided by law, and rendered a verdict of death by suicide.
            It was said that a note was found later, in which the girl gave instructions as to her burial.
            She leaves her father, mother and two brothers and a sister at home, and a sister living in Cincinnati. The funeral will be held Friday morning at the Summit Evangelical Church, and will be conducted by the pastor.           
 
1922
DEATH
Name:    Abraham EIKLEBERRY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Mar. 2, 1922
            Abraham EIKLEBERRY, one of the oldest and most highly respected citizens of this community, was claimed by death at his home Friday, February 24, 1922, being born on February 15, 1842, he was 80 years and 9 days old.
            He was born, reared, lived and died at the same home.
            In early manhood he united with the Church of Christ at West Union and lived a faithful consistent member all through his life.
            On April 17, 1866, he was united in marriage with Sarah A. GOUDY. Six children came to bless the home, all of whom are living, except one son who passed away several years ago. He leaves to mourn his wife, who was 77 years old February 26th, this being the day of Mr. Eikleberry’s funeral; two daughters, Mrs. James EDDY of Woodsfield and Mrs. Olive MAFFETT of Paden City, West Virginia; three sons, John and Micajah EIKLEBERRY of Sardis, Ohio, Route 1 and James EIKLEBERRY at home, also 20 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, Junior FEIOCK and Charles EDDY; besides a host of other relatives and friends.
            He was a kind and loving husband and father, a good friend and neighbor. His faults were few; a noble Christian worthy of imitation. His death was due to infirmities of old age. Funeral services were held at West Union Sunday, February 26th conducted by Elder W. H. THOMPSON and were largely attended.
            The grandchildren of the deceased acted as pallbearers.
 
1922
Emmit Beardmore
d-February 24, 1922

1922
DEATH
Name:    Daniel L. EGGER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Mar. 9, 1922
            The Daily Durango Democrat, published at Durango, Colorado, in its issue of February 25, 1922, contained the following account of the death of Daniel L. EGGER, mention of whose death was made in this paper last week:
            “News was received at this office early yesterday evening of the sudden death of Daniel L. EGGER, of The Bayfield Blade of apoplexy. Mr. Egger had suffered a few weeks ago from a stroke of rheumatism but had seemingly recovered from it and was as well as he had been for some time. He was helping with the chores about 6 o’clock and without warning dropped dead. He was about 60 years of age.
            “Mr. Egger established The Bayfield Blade and had been its owner and editor  continuously since its establishment nearly 14 years ago.
            “He was well known and well liked and his death will come as a shock to his many friends.
            “He leaves a wife and five children, three boys and two girls, three of whom are at home. Reef Egger runs the Pagosa Sun, while Marie is the reporter in the State Senate at Denver.
            “The arrangements for the funeral will await the arrival of the daughter from Denver. The funeral will probably be held next Monday at Bayfield.
            “Mr. Egger had been very closely identified with the history of the San Juan basin for a number of years and latterly had divided his time between the Blade and his fine farm near Bayfield.
            “His loss is one that will be felt by the community where he has labored so long and faithfully.”         
 
1922
Marshall, M.
d: Mar. 3, 1922
Moose, Mary C.
d: Mar. 2, 1922
1922
Craig, Ezra O.
d: Mar. 8, 1922
 
1922
DEATH
Name:    Aaron YOE
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Mar. 16, 1922
            Relatives here received word of the death of Aaron YOE at his home in Belmont county last Sunday night, March 12, 1922, aged 64 years, 9 months and 4 days.
            The remains were brought to Buchanan Station today (Wednesday) and will be laid to rest on Friday, conducted by the Elder C. L. MELLOTT of Woodsfield. The wife was sick and unable to come.
            Mr. Yoe was a native of Monroe county, Summit township, born near Lewisville on June 8, 1857, and taught school in this county a number of years before moving to Belmont. He joined the Presbyterian church at Buchanan in 1896, and after moving to Belmont county he joined the Christian church and lived a consistent Christian until the end.
            Mr. Yoe was the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Elijah YOE, pioneers of Summit township, leaves a wife and seven children - four girls and three boys besides a number of other relatives and friends. He is a brother of Emanuel YOE, near Lewisville and father of Mrs. George FOEHRENBACH of Wise Station and Mrs. William GELDMACHER near Middle church.
            He was a man of many fine qualities and will be sadly missed.
 
1922
DEATH
Name:    E. H. MENKEL
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio Thursday, Mar. 16, 1922
            Mr. Edward H. MENKEL, a prominent citizen of Woodsfield, died at his home on Sycamore street this (Wednesday) morning at 2:00 o’clock, aged about 54 years.
            He leaves besides his wife, nine children - Gilbert Leroy MENKEL, of Cushing, Oklahoma; Clyde MENKEL of Woodsfield; Mrs. Edna GUSTEL of Canton, Ohio; Mrs. Alma BIGLER of Steubenville, Ohio; Miss Cleo MENKEL, of Canton, Ohio; William H, Harold, Miss Pearl and Edward Junior MENKEL of Woodsfield. Also four brothers, Charles, Philip, and William O. MENKEL, of Miltonsburg and Theodore MENKEL of Ansonia, Ohio, and two sisters, Misses Julia and Lucinda MENKEL of Miltonsburg.
            The date of the funeral has not been definitely fixed, but will be Friday or Saturday of this week and will be conducted by the Independent Order of Oddfellows of which he was a member.
            The relatives have the sincere sympathy of many friends.

1922
DEATH
Name:   Maggie COATS, nee KEEVERT
Source: newspaper clipping, March 1922
            Maggie KEEVERT was born October 1, 1857; departed this live March 23, 1922, aged 64 years, 5 months and 22 days. She was married to J. W. COATS, December 25, 1902; was baptized into Christ in 1915, by S. D. HOWELL, being a member of the Mt. Zion Church of Christ in Adams township, Monroe County, Ohio. She leaves to mourn her departure her husband, J. W. COATS, one sister, Mrs. Jacob SCHNEIDER, a half sister, Mrs. William DICKEY of Jerusalem, Ohio; half brother, Charles KEEVERT of Kansas, besides many other relatives and friends. She was kind hearted to all and a good neighbor, sympathized with all that were in trouble or distress. Hers was the hand to help the needy and none were ever turned away from her door hungry, but her earthly life is spent and God has called her home.
            Why do we mourn departed                                     friends,
            Or shake at death’s alarms?
            ‘Tis but the voice that Jesus send
            To call us to his arms.                                                                           - Husband
1922
DEATH
Name:    David AFFOLTER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Mar. 30, 1922
            Relatives were notified of the sudden death of David AFFOLTER at Gridley, Kansas, last Monday, as a result of neuralgia of the heart. Mr. Affolter who is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel AFFOLTER of Jackson Ridge, and was well and favorably known in Woodsfield, where he was at one time located. He was a married man and his wife and family were located at Logan, Ohio, and they were arranging to join Mr. Affolter in Kansas when word of his death was received.
            The remains will be brought to Woodsfield and laid to rest in the family lot in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.
 
1922   XXXXX
DEATH
Name:    Lyman J. MANN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Mar. 30 & Apr. 6, 1922
            Another aged and lifelong citizen of Monroe has passed to the great beyond in the person of Lyman J. MANN, who died at his home on West Marietta street, Saturday evening, March 25, 1922, at 6:00 o’clock after a long illness from Bright’s disease.
            Mr. Mann was born in Malaga township, Monroe county, Ohio on the 4th of December, 1845, and was 76 years, 3 months and 21 days old, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hughes MANN. In the year, 1880, he was united in marriage with Mrs. Henrietta STENZEL of Miltonsburg. A family of three children were born to this union.
            He leaves an aged wife, son Paul MANN of Woodsfield and one daughter, Mrs. Ward VOSPE of Columbus; (one daughter Mrs. Leo O’ROURKE preceded him in death); two stepdaughters, Mrs. Theodore MENKEL of Ansonia, Ohio, and Mrs. James WHARTON of Jackson Ridge. Also two sisters, Mrs. Theodore THORNBERRY of Steubenville and Mrs. Loretta JOHNSTON of Woodsfield, eight grandchildren and a large circle of other relatives and friends survive.
            The funeral took place at the home last Monday afternoon, with Rev. George L. DAVIS of the M. E. church in charge, and his remains were laid to rest in Oaklawn cemetery.
            The funeral was attended by a large number of relatives and friends including the following from a distance: Mrs. M. A. EBERLE of Cambridge; L. D. O’ROURKE and three daughters, Carrie, Norma and Thelma of East Pittsburg, Pennsylvania; Dean GRAMLICH of Barnesville; Mr. and Mrs. Theo. THORNBERRY and Mrs. C. H. RINE of Steubenville; Mrs. T. F. MENKEL of Ansonia, Ohio; Mr. and Mrs. Ward VOSPER and son of Columbus; Misses Ella and Louise WATSON of Quaker City; Miss Emma GRAMLICH of Bridgeport, and Miss Matilda WHARTON of Bellaire.
            The floral offerings were many and very fine.
            Mr. Mann was a member of one of Monroe county’s most highly respected pioneer families, had many friends wherever known, and had spent his entire life in this county.
            The widow and family have the sincere sympathy of many friends. His memory will long be cherished by those who knew him for the kind and loving character he was.

Pryor, Joseph

1922
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Maria S. KUHLBORN
Source: Monroe County death records
and         St. John’s Church records
and         Newspaper clipping, April 1922
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
            Mrs. Maria Sophia KUHLBORN (KILBURN), aged 87 years, 6 months and 3 days, died March 31, 1922, at her home in Malaga township, Monroe County.
            Mrs. Kuhlborn, nee LINGE, was the widow of the late John Henry KUHLBORN (KILBURN). She was born September 28, 1834, in Schammburg, Germany, and came to this country in 1856. She was married, the same year to Mr. Kuhlborn. She and her husband first resided in Kentucky, removing in 1866, to Malaga township, Monroe County, where they resided the remainder of their lives. They were blessed with seven children.
            She leaves four children, Mrs. Lusetta KIRSCH of Somerton, Belmont County; Mrs. Sophia PFALZGRAF of Lewisville, Ohio; and Messrs. Henry and Gustav KUHLBORN (KILBURN) of Lewisville. She also leaves fifteen grandchildren and twenty-four great grandchildren.
            Mrs. Kuhlborn was a faithful member of the Evangelical Church in Summit township, where the funeral and burial was held on April 3, 1922, in St. John’s Middle Church cemetery in Summit township, Monroe County, Ohio.

1922
DEATH
Name:    Caroline TAYLOR, nee WILLIS
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, April 6, 1922
            Mrs. Caroline TAYLOR (nee WILLIS) was born March 9, 1844, and died March 30, 1922, aged 78 years and 21 days. She was married to Thomas H. TAYLOR on April 26, 1866. To this union were born six children - two sons and four daughters. The oldest and youngest girls preceded their mother in death. She is survived by two sons, Emory S. and Mayor Edward D. TAYLOR of Woodsfield, and two daughters, Mrs. George F. GERTLER of Rushville, Indiana, and Mrs. Ralph LOWER of Columbiana, Ohio, and one brother, two sisters and five grandchildren.
            For almost sixty years Mrs. Taylor was a faithful member of the M. E. church and was a lady of many fine qualities. A host of relatives and friends are left to mourn her loss and respect her memory.

DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Mary Ann MILLER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Apr. 13, 1922
            Mrs. Mary Ann MILLER, nee CROCK, widow of the late John MILLER of Miltonsburg died at the home of her son Andrew MILLER in Barnesville, Ohio, April 4, 1922, at 8:55 a.m., aged 75 years, 7 months and 12 days.
            Mrs. Miller was a devoted member of St. John’s Catholic church at Miltonsburg, and a woman of fine character.
            Among the immediate relatives left to mourn her loss are 8 children - Andrew MILLER of Barnesville; Mrs. Michael WAHL of Woodsfield Route 3; Edward MILLER of Jerusalem Route 4; Mrs. Fred WAHL of Miltonsburg; Sebastian MILLER of White Lake, South Dakota; Leonard MILLER of Jerusalem Route 4 and Mrs. William REISCHMAN of Barnesville. Also one sister and one brother - Mrs. Michael FORNES of Columbus, Ohio, and Mr. Casper CROCK of Woodsfield, besides many other relatives and friends.
            Two children - Mrs. George BURKHART and Mrs. George MILLER preceded her in death.
            Funeral services were held Thurs. morning, April 6th, at the Church of the Assumption in Barnesville, Ohio, conducted by Rev. William ROBBEN and interment was made at Miltonsburg.

DEATH
Name:    Jesse O. HALL
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Apr. 13, 1922
            Jesse O. HALL, son of Enoch and Mary L. HALL, was born in Bethel township, Monroe county, Ohio, August 25, 1874, and died at Jolly, Ohio, March 20, 1922, aged 47 years, 7 months and 5 days. He was united in marriage to Miss Della STEWART October 28, 1896. To this union were born four sons, all of whom survive.
            Funeral services were conducted by Rev. W. A. WEDDLE, of Jericho, in the Christian church at 1 p.m. April 1st after which the remains were laid to rest in the U. P. cemetery. He leaves to mourn his departure his aged father and mother, the wife, four sons, three brothers, two sisters, and many other relatives and friends.

1922
DEATH
Name:    Edward WEBER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Apr. 20, 1922
            The many friends of Edward WEBER and family of Buchanan Station were shocked to learn that his lifeless remains had been found in an old well near his barn last Sunday morning. The facts as near as we can learn were as follows:
            Mr. Weber sometime before had suffered from a severe attack of lagrippe which had left him in poor health. He was not despondent, however, as he had received the most careful attention by his family and friends and physician.
            Sunday morning about 5:00 o’clock Mr. Weber awoke and asked about a drink of water. Mrs. Weber offered to get one, but he arose and went out doors. When he did not return, Mrs. Weber became puzzled, then alarmed. She searched, and after failing to find her husband, called the assistance of neighbors, and after some time Mr. Weber’s remains were found in a well near the barn. While a verdict of suicide was rendered by acting Corner John W. FEIOCK, there is room for doubt and the possibility that he fell in the well, which may have been uncovered by other ways than by himself.
            In addition to suffering from the effects of the flu, Mr. Weber had been injured by a cellar door, and that his physician had warned him to avoid any great exertion.
            The funeral took place last Thursday afternoon when services were conducted by his pastor, Rev. J. J. SRODES of Woodsfield and were attended by an unusually large number of friends from far and near. The remains were laid to rest in Buchanan cemetery.
            Mr. Weber was an elder in the Buchanan Presbyterian church, a very substantial church member, an exemplary citizen, husband and father of many good qualities.
            He leaves his wife and three young children; father, Christopher WEBER; a sister, Mrs. Henry YOUNG; and three brothers, John, David and Will WEBER, all of near Lewisville. He was a lifelong resident of his section of the county where he resided at the time of his death.
 
1922
Thompson, E. O.
d: Apr. 1, 1922
1922
Colvin, Carrie O.
d: May 3, 1922
 
1922
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Elizabeth KESTNER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., May 25, 1922
            Mrs. Elizabeth KESTNER, nee ECKARD, wife of Fred KESTNER, was born in Monroe county, Ohio, March 28, 1857, and departed this life at her home near Ashland, Ohio, April 28, 1922, aged 64 years and one month.
            She was united in marriage with Fred KESTNER June 27, 1880, and to this union were born six children, Edward, William, Leonard, and George KESTNER, and Mrs. Carl FRANCE. One daughter, Freda KESTNER, preceded her in death May 22, 1908. Two sisters survive her, Mrs. Mary RHINES and Mrs. Louise BLUM, both of Swissvale, Pennsylvania. Six grandchildren also survive.
            The funeral was held Monday, May 1st, at 10:30 o’clock from the Peace Evangelical Lutheran church in Ashland, conducted by her pastor, Rev. Carl D. FISCHER. Mrs. Kestner was a sister of the late Mrs. Philip J. WEBER of Woodsfield, and her husband formerly resided at Lewisville. Both have relatives and many friends in this county who will sympathize with Mr. Kestner in his sad loss.
            Relatives who attended from a distance were Mr. and Mrs. George KESTNER of Pittsburg; Mrs. Louise BLUM of Swissvale, Pa; Mike KESTNER of Lewisville, Ohio, and Philip WEBER and daughter Miss Minnie of Woodsfield.

1922
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Mattie L. DYER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, June 1, 1922
            Mrs. Mattie L. DYER, daughter of Alex and Mary Jane SIMERAL, was born September 11, 1868, near Ozark, Monroe county, Ohio, where she grew to womanhood and united with the M. E. church of that place.
            She was united in marriage October 5, 1893, to John W. DYER. To this union was born three children who are all living and were present.
            They are Clifford DYER, who is married and lives at Lock 17; Raymond and Minnie DYER at home, besides these she leaves to mourn her loss her husband, one sister, Mrs. Lawson CLARK of Barnesville, and one brother, J. C. SIMERAL of Ozark, Ohio. Her father, mother and sister Minnie SIMERAL having preceded her to the great beyond.
            She, with her family, moved to Tuscarawas county March 13, 1913, where she resided until death took her from us. She had been in poor health for some time with heart trouble and all medical skill and loving hands could do was of no avail. She departed this life May 18, 1922.
            She was loved by all who knew her and will be sadly missed in the home and by her friends and neighbors.     
 
1922
DEATH
Name:    George SCOTT
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, June 8, 1922
            George SCOTT, a very highly respected citizen of Lewisville, who was engaged in the hardware business, died at his home in that place Sunday evening, June 4, 1922, of pneumonia, after a short illness. He leaves a wife, his mother, Mrs. Martha SCOTT, and two brothers, Andrew J. and William SCOTT, besides many other relatives and friends.
            The funeral was held Tuesday afternoon and was largely attended. The Knights of Pythias Lodge, of which he was a member, had charge of the funeral.

DEATH
Name:    Miss Nettie BUSKIRK
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, July 6, 1922
            Miss Nettie BUSKIRK died at her home at Round Bottom Monday night, June 26, 1922, after a few days’ illness from pneumonia and complications. She had been a semi-invalid for years, but her death came as a shock to hundreds of friends to eastern Monroe county. She was about forty-five years of age and is survived by her father, Dr. N. P. BUSKIRK, who is seriously ill himself, and two brothers Alonzo BUSKIRK of Moundsville and Gussie BUSKIRK at home.
            Funeral services were held Thursday afternoon, June 29th, at 2:00 o’clock at the home.

1922
DEATH
Name:   Roy STIMPERT
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., July 20, 1922
            Roy F. STIMPERT of Miltonsburg died Saturday afternoon of tuberculosis after an illness of several months. He was born February 25, 1894, and died July 15, 1922, the sum total of his earthly days being 28 years, 4 months and 20 days.
            December 25, 1907, he united with the Evangelical church through the sacred rites of confirmation and remained a faithful member until God called him to this eternal rest.
            On November 13, 1918, he was married to Miss Elizabeth KAUFMAN. This union was blessed with two sons, Junior and Cecil STIMPERT, who were his pride and comfort. Besides his loving wife and children he leaves father, mother and two sisters, Mrs. Jacob WILSON of Barnesville and Mrs. Waldo EGGER of Akron; also an aged grandfather, Frederick BAKER, all being at his bedside during his sickness and death.
            Although Roy had not been in good health for some time, no one thought the end was so near until July 3rd, he became suddenly worse and continued so until he answered the call, “Come unto me all ye that labor and are weak and heavy laden and I will give ye rest.”
            Mr. Stimpert was not only a good husband and father, but was a man of many other endearing qualities as a neighbor and progressive citizen.
            He was a leading member of Miltonsburg Grange and a worker for the success of agriculture in every particular.
            The funeral took place Tuesday with religious services by Rev. Joseph REINIKE of St. Paul’s Evangelical church and burial ceremonies of the Grange. The funeral was largely attended and the remains were laid to rest in the family lot in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.
 
1922
DEATH
Name: George WALTER
Source: Monroe county death records
            George Walter died July 7, 1922. He was born April 8, 1857, the son of Heinrich and Anna Maria “Mary” SCHMITT WALTER.
1922
DEATH
Name:   James Jacob NEUHARDT
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Aug. 3, 1922
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
            It is with sadness we are called upon to note the departure of our friend and neighbor, James Jacob NEUHARDT, son of John Michael and Mary Catherine SCHAUB NEUHART. John Michael died September 11, 1909, in Monroe County, Ohio and Mary Catherine died in 1890. James Jacob was born August 1, 1857, at the Neuhardt homestead in Summit township, Monroe County, Ohio, and departed this life July 9, 1922, at the Good Samaritan Hospital, Zanesville, Ohio. On Sunday, November 12, 1885, he was married to Miss Lucetta BINTZ. To this union were born five children of which two daughters, Clara Lucetta and Harriett Magdelina gone to the world beyond. Harriett Magdelina NEUHARDT died March 3, 1911.
            Just a week before he passed away he seemed to be enjoying life as usual when suddenly on Sunday afternoon, July 2, he was stricken ill. His case was placed in the physician and upon his advice it was deemed best to go to the hospital where he was placed in the hands of the surgeons. Although his condition was serious they thought it best to try the gallstone operation. This for a time seemed to be successful, then uremic poisoning set in which resulted in his death. Before he started to the hospital, he expressed the thought that perhaps he might never return but was ready to face death. He was accompanied by his faithful wife, who at his request never left him until the end came.
            On Sunday afternoon, July 2, the body was brought from Zanesville to the home to await the funeral services which were held in the German M. E. Church near Monroefield, Ohio, on Wednesday morning, July 12, and the remains were laid to rest in the cemetery therein the presence of a large number of friends and relatives. The services were conducted by the Reverend Theodore LAGFEMANN of Hopkins, Michigan, a former pastor and friend.
            He was a kind husband and devoted father and he will be sadly missed in the home and in the community in which he has spent his life, but we can only say “Thy will, Lord, and not ours be done.”
            He leaves to mourn his loss, his beloved wife, Lucetta BINTZ NEUHARDT, three children, Franklin Samuel Neuhardt and Arthur Frederick NEUHARDT of near Lewisville and Mrs. Charlotte Amelia NEUHARDT SLOAN of Miltonsburg; three grandchildren, two brothers, George E. NEUHARDT of Memphis, Tennessee, and Henry J. Neuhardt of Moundsville, West Virginia; five sisters, Mary and Elizabeth NEUHARDT and Katherine HARRIGON of Barnesville, Mrs. Ernestine THOMPSON of Shadyside, Amelia NEUHARDT of Wheeling, West Virginia, and Mrs. Mollie DINZER  who spent a portion of her life in the Neuhardt home. Two brothers, Philip NEUHARDT of Barnesville, Ohio and John NEUHARDT of Lukee, Mississippi have gone before. Besides these there are numerous other relatives and friends who will sadly miss him from our midst. To all these, we extend our heartfelt sympathy and may all look to our Heavenly Father for help and guidance throughout life’s pathway. 
 
1922
Gilmore, Nimrod
d: Aug. 7, 1922
 
1922
Howell, unnamed
d: Aug. 6, 1922
 
1922
DEATH
Name:  Jesse Carl HOSSMAN
Source: Monroe County death records
and        The Monroe County Republican
Woodsfield, Ohio, August 1922
Collection of Wilda Heft Bartenschlag
            On Sunday afternoon, August 6, 1922, our community was shocked and saddened by the death of Jesse Carl HOSSMAN who was born August 21, 1888, in Ohio township, Monroe County, Ohio, the son of Carl and Alice Hossman.
             On June 30, 1917, he was united in marriage to Miss Oneda CHRISTMAN. To this happy union one son, Elwood C. HOSSMAN was born July 22, 1921. Shortly after their marriage they moved to a farm near Miltonsburg, Ohio but about a year ago they purchased a farm near Lewisville at which place they resided at the time of his death.
            For several years Mr. Hossman had been suffering from organic heart trouble and had gone to many doctors but did not seem to get much relief.
            A short time ago he was seriously ill with pneumonia but had seemingly recovered from that sufficiently to walk about the house, but conditions arising from the diseased heart could not be overcome until the Great physician reached out his hand and claimed him for a higher reward.
            During his early youth he united with the Evangelical Church at Miltonsburg by confirmation and remained a faithful member until God called him to the Church above.  For several years before he moved away he served as superintendent in the Sunday school at that place.
            The last few years of his life he was County Grange Deputy and has done a great deal of organization work among the granges of this County. He was also leader of the Barnhart Poultry Club and will be sadly missed by the young people of the club. He has always taken an active interest in all things pertaining to the welfare of the farming communities. He was a good citizen and neighbor, a devoted husband and father and although it is hard to give him up in youth, we know that God has something greater in store for him and sometime we’ll understand his plan.
            On Tuesday afternoon at one o’clock the funeral services were conducted at St. John’s Middle Church by the Rev. Wm. DALLMAN of Lewisville, Ohio with undertaker Bauer in attendance before a large assemblage of friends and relatives. At the grave short and impressive service was conducted by the Miltonsburg and Barnhart granges.
            The deceased leaves to mourn his departure his wife, Mrs. Oneda  HOSSMAN, one son, Elwood Charles HOSSMAN, father, mother, Mr. and Mrs. Carl HOSSMAN, six brothers, Fred, Charles, Wesley, Raymond, Elmer and Victor HOSSMAN, two sisters, Miss Freda HOSSMAN and Mrs. Clem CLAUS all living  near  Miltonsburg, Ohio  and  an aged  grandmother, Mrs. Magdelene SIGENTHALER of Round Bottom. May God be with them in their hour of desolation.                                 V. L. F.
 
1922
Sebastian N. Archer
d-September 2, 1922
 
1922
 McKelvey, Stillborn
d: August 28, 1922
1922
John W. Baker
d-September 10, 1922
 
 
1922XXXXX
DEATH
Name:    Sebastian N. ARCHER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, September 14, 1922
            Sebastian N. ARCHER was born June 16, 1844, in what is now Noble county, near East Union. He was the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elijah ARCHER pioneer settlers on the East Fork of Duck Creek.
            The deceased was 78 years, 2 months, and 16 days old. October 9, 1864, he was united in marriage to Miss Ellen  McGOVERN  at  the  Fulda  Catholic church by Rev. Father FLUBER. Immediately after the marriage Mr. Archer was called to serve his country in the Civil War. He was honorably discharged from the service at Camp Chase, Ohio, in the fall of 1865.
            Ten children were born to Mr. and Mrs. Archer, the oldest and youngest dying in infancy. His wife and eight children still survive: A. C. ARCHER of Zanesville, Ohio; U. W. of Somerset; E. P. ARCHER of Lewisville; A. J. ARCHER of Youngstown, and Thomas ARCHER of Columbus; Mrs. Thurman SMITH of Caldwell; Rosa McENTEE and Lucy DANFORD of the home. Mr. Archer is also survived by one brother, J. W. ARCHER of the home place and one sister, Mrs. Michael CRUM of near East Union.
            Mr. Archer was honored and respected by all who knew him. He was a devout member of the Catholic church. His has been a long and useful life and he has left to his sons and daughters no legacy more valuable than the example he set before them. May they always remember this in their different walks of life and may this be a guiding star to steer them in the path of righteousness.
            The funeral was held at St. Sylvester’s Catholic church at Woodsfield, Ohio, and he was laid to rest in the cemetery at that place, followed by a large concourse of relatives and friends among which was the local G. A. R. Post carrying the flag and flowers. May he rest in peace.
 
1922
Stephen, David P.
d: Sept. 8, 1922
 
1922
Sims, Jacob F.
d: Sept. 17, 1922
           
1922
DEATH
Name:    Elmer Benjamin HAREN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 28, 1922
            Miltonsburg, Ohio community was shocked and saddened by the rather sudden death of Elmer B. HAREN, of Hope Ridge. He was son of the late John B. HAREN and Mrs. Lucetta B. HAREN. Death came to him quite unexpectedly, yet peacefully, on Thursday, September 21 at 12:10 p.m. At his bedside were Rev. B. J. MATTES, his pastor, who administered the last rites of the church; Drs. GILLESPIE and son, in attendance; his mother; his sister Rosa HAREN; his brother Ralph HAREN; Miss Esther ZWICK, a relative; Miss Bernice CUNEAT, a friend, and latter two visiting from Stark county. Burial took place at St. John’s church, Saturday, September 23, at 9:30 with Requiem High Mass followed by the solemn Absolution of the Roman Catholic ritual, sung by his sorrowing pastor and a large attendance of relatives and friends. In official attendance were the Holy Name Society, and the local Grange, both of which Mr. Haren was a lifelong member. In his sermon, which was a beautiful tribute to the worth of the young man to his community by which his always willing services will long be missed, the Rev. pastor gave a striking message on the worth of a truly Christian life which will long be remembered by the large number in attendance privileged to hear it.
            Elmer B. HAREN was born January 29, 1898, and died at the age of 24 years, 7 months and 23 days. He is mourned by his sister, Rosa B., and Mary E. HAREN of the home; three brothers, Lawrence M. HAREN of Woodsfield route 3; Richard J. HAREN of Woodsfield route 4, and Ralph F. HAREN of he home. May he rest in peace, as his faith consoles his mourners.
1922
Workman, Hattie H.
d: Sept. 21, 1922

DEATH
Name:   Joseph P. BURKHART
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Nov.  2, 1922
            Joseph P. BURKHART of Kuhn, Ohio died at the Good Samaritan Hospital in Zanesville, Ohio Sunday morning October 15, 1922, following an operation. Bauer & Willison, Woodsfield funeral directors, were called and the remains brought to his home.
            The funeral took place Wednesday of last week and was conducted by Rev. Father IGEL. Interment in Chapel Hill cemetery near Burkhart Station.

DEATH
Name:   John M. BOUGHNER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Nov. 9, 1922
            John M. BOUGHNER, a very highly respected pioneer citizen, died at his home in Cameron, Ohio, September 25, 1922, aged 73 years and 9 months. He leaves to mourn his death a devoted wife, two daughters, Mrs. Myrta TIDD and Mrs. John HENTHORN of Cameron, also two brothers Elias and James M. BOUGHNER besides many other relatives and friends.

1922
DEATH
Name:   G. W. ROSS
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Nov. 9, 1922
            George Washington ROSS, Civil War veteran and most highly respected citizen, died at his home in Cameron, Ohio, Sunday evening, October 29, 1922, aged 81 years and 25 days, leaving but one Civil War veteran (William TIDD) still living in Adams township. Mr. Ross leaves besides many friends one son, Clarence ROSS, of Bridgeport, Ohio, and two daughters, Rosa and Anna ROSS at the home.

1922
DEATH
Name:   Lydia Ann CRAWFORD
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Nov. 16, 1922
            Lydia Ann CRAWFORD, daughter of John and Sarah MARPLE, died Sunday, November 12, 1922, aged 63 years, 8 months and 11 days. She was married to William Burkley CRAWFORD in 1878. To this union seven children were born -six boys and one girl. Mrs. Crawford obeyed the gospel in her eighteenth year, was baptized by Joseph DUNN and remained a faithful Christian until death. Funeral services were conducted by J. A. HINES. Interment in Calais cemetery.
 
1922
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Sophia GRIFFITH
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Nov. 16, 1922
            Another very highly respected lady has passed from earth to heaven in the person of Mrs. Sophia COOL GRIFFITH, who died at her home on High street, Wednesday, November 9, 1922, aged 87 years, 7 months and 7 days - a long life, well filled with good deeds.
            Mrs. Griffith was born at West Alexander, Pennsylvania April 1, 1835, and was married to Thomas J. GRIFFITH September 19, 1861. To this union four children were born - Alva, Ella, Lucy and Charles GRIFFITH. The two sons died early in life. Ella and Lucy are still living at the home.
            Mrs. Griffith lived near Beallsville for many years, but had been a resident of Woodsfield for the past 28 years where no lady was held in higher esteem. She became a member of the Presbyterian church at West Alexander, Pa. in early girlhood and continued her splendid church life at the Beallsville and Woodsfield Presbyterian churches.
            Funeral services were held at the home last Friday afternoon with her pastor, Rev. SRODES in charge. The floral offerings were numerous and a splendid tribute to respect. The remains, accompanied by many Woodsfield relatives and friends were taken to Beallsville and laid to rest beside her husband.
            We with many other friends extend sympathy to the bereaved daughters.

Name:   Louise C. YOUNG
Source: Monroe County Death records                              Louise Catherine NEUHART YOUNG was born August 24, 1849; daughter of Heinrich ‘Michael’ and Johanna NEUHART died December 15, 1922; aged 73 years, 3 months, and 21 days; burial in St. John’s Middle Church near Lewisville, Ohio.

DEATH
Name:   R. F. McCASLIN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Dec. 7, 1922
            Robert F. McCASLIN, a highly respected citizen of Round Bottom, died Friday, December 1, 1922, of pneumonia following an attack of measles, aged 51 years. He leaves a wife and many other relatives and friends. The funeral services in charge of Rev. William PARSONS of Woodsfield were held last Monday afternoon. Interment at Chapel Hill cemetery.
1922
DEATH
Name:   Frederick KETTERER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Dec. 14, 1922
            Frederick KETTERER, 18-year old son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. KETTERER, died at his home near Columbus, Ohio, at 5:00 o’clock last Sunday evening, December 10, 1922, of throat trouble. The funeral took place Tuesday afternoon and was attended by Mr. and Mrs. Charles KETTERER of Woodsfield. Interment at Columbus. Frederick was the only child of Mr. and Mrs. George KETTERER, former residents of Miltonsburg, Ohio and they have the sincere sympathy of many Monroe county friends.

DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Elizabeth BURGBACHER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Dec. 14, 1922
            Mrs. Elizabeth BURGBACHER, widow of Jacob BURGBACHER, died at her home in Woodsfield, Thursday evening, December 7, 1922, aged about 86 years. She was a lady of many fine qualities and will be sadly missed by relatives and friends. The funeral, conducted by Rev. Joseph REINICKE, occurred last Sunday afternoon. Interment in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.
