1922   XXXXX
 DEATH
 Name:  George A. G. MORRIS
 Source:  Death Certificate, Obituary
 Collection of Betty Latta Kitchen
     We have a copy of his certificate of death filled out by Georgiana Morris, his second wife.  His age is listed as 90 years 7 months and 18 days, and he died of pneumonia (lobar) December 27, 1922.  It says he is a retired farmer who was born in Noble County, Ohio.  Georgiana indicated that she did not know the names or birthplaces of his parents.  The words "pension copy issued" is stamped on this death form indicating he served in the Civil War.
 
 His obituary read:                DEATH OF GEORGE A. MORRIS
                               Had Been a Resident of Topeka for Fifty-Two Years
      "George A. Morris, 90, for fifty-two years a resident of Topeka, died Wednesday afternoon at his home, 1528 North Van Buren street.  Born in Mabel county [this should be NOBLE county], Ohio, he came to Kansas in its early days, and for many years was a farmer.
      "He retired from active work many years ago, and since that time has made his home in Topeka.
      "He is survived by his widow, Mrs. Georgiania [sic] Morris, and five children:  Mrs. Freeman Sardou, Sarah E. Morris and Mrs. R.K. Hyatt, of Topeka; James Morris, Old Mexico; and Mrs. Luella Whiteside, Carthage, MO."
 
1922
DEATH
Name:   Philip J. SCHUMACHER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Dec. 28, 1922
            Philip SCHUMACHER, one of Woodsfield’s oldest and most highly respected citizens and business men, died at his home on Eastern avenue, Woodsfield, Ohio Thursday morning, December 21, 1922, at 12:30 o’clock, after an illness of many months.
            Mr. Schumacher was born in Schoenau, Bavaria, Germany, on the 17th of October 1845, and was therefore 77 years, two months and four days old. He moved with his parents Philip and Elisabeth SCHUMACHER to America when quite young and located in Miltonsburg, Ohio, where the family lived only a few years before coming to Woodsfield.
            In 1868, he was married to Miss Anna M. LANG, who survives. To this union were born, Edward SCHUMACHER of Columbus, Clarence and William SCHUMACHER and Mrs. Stella SMITH of Woodsfield.
            Mr. Schumacher was a member of St. Paul’s Evangelical church, Woodsfield Independent Order of Oddfellows and was identified with many other good movements. He followed the bakery and grocery business all his life, and was always regarded as a strictly honest and reliable man.
            The funeral took place last Saturday with religious services by his pastor, Rev. Joseph REINICKE, with the ritualistic services of the I. O. O. F. added as a tribute of respect.
            The floral offerings were many and very fine. Interment in Oaklawn cemetery.
 
1923
Schaub, Harry A.
d: 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:    John H. EGGER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Jan. 4, 1923
            John H. EGGER of the Hilltop Farm near Miltonsburg, died very suddenly at his home at 2:00 o’clock, Tuesday, January 2, 1923. The news of his sudden death came as a severe shock not only to relatives but to his many other friends.
            The funeral will take place next Sunday morning, at 10:00 o’clock from the home. A request for no flowers comes from the family.
            The widow and other relatives have the sincere sympathy of many friends.
 
1923
MARRIAGE
Names: Mr. Harry JOHNSTON
and          Miss Nellie KELLER
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 11, 1923
            Married, on December 26, 1923, at the home of W. M. JOHNSTON, the Groom’s father, Miss Nellie Keller of Graysville, Ohio and Mr. Harry Johnston of Sycamore Valley. The marriage ceremony was performed by J. F. CLIFT, Esq., and was a grand affair, which made them man and wife. After the marriage ceremony congratulations were extended to the bride and groom, after which they were marched with their friends to the dining room where they were seated around the table, loaded down with all that the appetite could wish for and of which all partook freely except J. f. CLIFT, who failed to have capacity to satisfy his appetite and James KNOWLTON had to be persuaded to leave the table for fear of overeating after supper. They were given an old-fashioned serenade by a large crowd which had gathered, and who all extended congratulations to the happy married couple. Then came the treat which consisted of candy, pie, cake and stogies. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Chris UNGER, Mr. and Mrs. Charles MASSIE, Ula, Garnet, Vera and Garold UNGER, Clarence KNOWLTON, Mr. and Mrs. James KNOWLTON, Orian KNOWLTON, F. LAW, Mr. and Mrs. Gus MARSHALL, Mr. and Mrs. C. H. ULLMAN, Mr. and Mrs. G. B. McFADDEN, Harold BURKHART, Mr. and Mrs. John BURKHART, John F. CLIFT, Esq., Mr. and Mrs. W. M. JOHNSTON. After distribution of presents, which were many and appropriate, the guests were entertained by music, vocal and instrumental, with Miss Hattie JOHNSTON and Mr. Charles MASSIE at the piano. After which the crowd dispersed reporting a good time.
                        -One Who Was There
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   William FISHER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio,Thurs., Jan. 11, 1923
            William Fisher of Chicago, died December 15, 1922, at the age of 78 years. He was born at Lewisville, Ohio, this county. He was a son of John FISHER and brother of Garrison and Joseph FISHER who have preceded him several years ago. One brother Isaac FISHER of Beallsville, Arkansas, is still living. he was an uncle of Mrs. C. E. WEBER of Woodsfield.
            He enlisted in Co. E, 116th. O. V. L. in August, 1862, at the age of 18 years and served to the end of the war. He was united in marriage with Miss Sarah GUTHRIDGE. To this union two children were born, Charles and Maggie FISHER, who live to mourn his loss. He was laid to rest in the family lot in Oakwood cemetery, Chicago. 
 
1923XXXX
MARRIAGE
Names:  Mr. John BUSCHE
and          Miss Marjorie BILLMAN
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 11, 1923
            Mr. John Busche, of Sardis, Ohio, and Miss Marjorie Billman of Lewisville, ohio, were united in marriage December 23rd, 1922, at New Martinsville, West Virginia. The wedding ceremony was performed by Rev. MILESS, of the M. E. parsonage. After the ceremony, the young people motored to Lewisville to the home of the bride’s parents. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. BILLMAN of Lewisville. She is one of Monroe county’s progressive young teachers and at present is employed as primary teacher in the Sardis schools. The groom is the youngest son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip BUSCHE of Sardis, Ohio, and is a well known prosperous young farmer of that community. Both are highly respected young people and their many friends wish them success.

             "Morris, Martha, widow of Thomas Morris died Wednesday [January 10], survived by son, Norval and daughter Mrs. W. D. Brown.  Buried Olive."
 
1923XXXXX
DEATH
Name:   Dr. Noah P. BUSKIRK
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 25, 1923
            Dr. Noah P. BUSKIRK, one of Monroe county’s most highly respected citizens, died at his home in Round Bottom on Tuesday night, January 16, 1923, of chronic Bright’s disease, aged 78 years, 5 months and 12 days. He was a brother of Dennis BUSKIRK, formerly with The Spirit of Democracy, and leaves two sons, Alonzo and R. A. BUSKIRK.
            Dr. Buskirk spent his entire life at Round Bottom, and had many friends wherever known. He was a member of Monroe Lodge No. 189 Free and Accepted Masons, by whom he was universally respected as a loyal Mason and exemplary citizen.
            The funeral took place last Friday, with Rev. William PARSONS in charge. Several Masons from Woodsfield were in attendance and performed the last sad rites for a faithful brother. Dr. Buskirk’s remains were laid to rest in the Salem church cemetery.
            The bereaved relatives have the sincere sympathy of many friends.
           
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Frank SCHWALL
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 25, 1923
            Francis, commonly called Frank SCHWALL died January 9, 1923, at a Columbus, Ohio hospital, following an operation for piles, which was made on his birthday, December 31 last.
            Mr. Schwall was a lifelong citizen of this town and immediate vicinity, where he had won the respect of all who knew him. He was born in Center township December 31, 1859, and was therefore 63 years, 9 days old at the time of his death.
            Francis SCHWALL was a member of St. Paul’s Evangelical church, where he was baptized and confirmed many years ago. In May 1883, he was united in marriage to Miss Sophia, who survives him, with two sons, Edward SCHWALL of Woodsfield and Walter SCHWALL of Columbus. He also leaves four grand children and one brother, Chris SCHWALL of Woodsfield, also two sisters, Mrs. Elizabeth LEIBFARTH of Marietta and Mrs. Esther GORTH of Covington, Kentucky.
            The remains were brought to his home in this place, and funeral services, conducted by his pastor, Rev. Joseph REINICKE were held Friday morning, January 12th, and were well attended.
            Mr. Schwall was a stone mason by trade, a highly respected citizen and will be missed by many friends in Woodsfield besides his family.
           
1923
Ischy, Elizabeth
d: Jan. 17, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Mary DOUGHERTY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 25, 1923
            Mrs. Mary DOUGHERTY, one of Woodsfield’s oldest and most highly respected citizens - widow of John DOUGHERTY formerly of Sixteen, this county, and mother of Mrs. Lorena STRICKLING of Wayne township and Mrs. Joseph BURKHART of near Woodsfield, died at her home in Woodsfield, Ohio Sunday evening, January 21, 1923, of pneumonia, aged 90 years, 6 months and 7 days.
            Mrs. Dougherty was a most highly respected citizen, and one of the oldest members of the Monroe County August Flower Association.
            The funeral took place this (Wednesday) afternoon at the home with Elder J. A. HINES in charge. Interment beside her husband in Moose Ridge cemetery.
1923
DEATH
Name:   Henry Harvey TURNER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 25, 1923
            Henry Harvey TURNER, widely known and very highly respected citizen of Wayne township, Monroe county, Ohio, died at his home on Cranes Nest creek Thursday morning, January 18, 1923, of pulmonary pneumonia, aged 68 years, 6 months and 21 days. He was born in Franklin township, Monroe county in 1854, the son of James F.  and Jane TURNER, and spent his entire life in this county where he was justice of the peace and a citizen of many good qualities.
            In 1891, he became a member of Woodsfield Lodge No. 377, Independent Order Of Odd Fellows, and remained a faithful member until death - - ever ready to do his duty as a brother Odd Fellow.
            He joined the M. P. church on Moose Ridge in 1911, and lived the Christian life until called to the home above.
            Brother Turner leaves a devoted wife and thirteen children - four daughters and nine sons, all of whom were in attendance at the funeral, held at the home and conducted by his pastor, Rev. C. W. CARTWRIGHT of Lewisville, Ohio. The remains were brought to Woodsfield and laid to rest in Oaklawn cemetery with the honors and impressive ceremony of the Independent Order of Oddfellows, last Saturday.
            Well, tired friend, rest in peace.
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   John TISHER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 25, 1923
            John TISHER an aged and highly respected citizen of this place, and a veteran of the Civil War, being a member of the 25th Ohio, Company C., died at his home Monday morning, January 8, 1923, after an illness of many months, aged 85 years. The deceased is survived by one son and four daughters: David TISHER, Mrs. H. W. SCHAUB, and Misses Phoebe and Eliza TISHER of this place, and Mrs. Arthur KENT of Portland, Oregon, besides two grandchildren, one brother and two sisters, and a host of other relatives. The funeral services were conducted on Wednesday afternoon by his pastor, Rev. C. F. WALTERS of the M. E. church, of which the deceased was a faithful member and were largely attended.
            The Ladies’ Circle G. A. R. was present in a body and conducted their ritualistic services and the member of the American Legion in uniform acted as pall bearers.
            Interment was in the family lot in the Harter cemetery beside his wife who preceded him eighteen years ago. There were beautiful floral offerings.
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Jacob LUDE
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Feb. 1, 1923
            Jacob LUDE, a very highly respected citizen, died suddenly at his home on Route 3 Clarington, Ohio January 25, 1923.
            He was stricken with paralysis on August 2, 1922, and had been almost helpless since that time. While his death was not entirely expected it came as a shock to the entire community.
            He was born July 19, 1862, being at he time of his death 60 years, 6 months and 6 days old. The son of George and Mary Ann LUDE.
            He was united with the Evangelical Lutheran church in his sixteenth year, and was a consistent member until his death.
            He was married to Emma WICHTERMAN, October 9, 1888. He is survived by the widow and the following children: Adda M., Albert L. and Edwin LUDE, Mrs. Earl BURKHALTER, Mrs. Andrew FORSHEY and Mrs. Wesley DIERKES. Also four grand daughters, two brothers, Michael LUDE of Sardis and C W. LUDE of Ravenna, and one sister, Mrs. Agnes COULTER of Pittsburg, and a host of other relatives and friends. His eldest brother, Chris LUDE, preceded him in death January 1, 1922.
            The funeral was held Sunday forenoon. Interment in the St. James cemetery, Rev. A. E. KITTERER of Powhatan conducted the services.
 
1923
Green, Ida N.
d: Jan. 27, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:  John FELDNER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Feb. 8, 1923
            John FELDNER of Eastern Avenue, Woodsfield, Ohio, died Thursday, February 1, 1923, and was buried from St. Paul’s Evangelical church Sunday afternoon February 4th.
            Mr. Feldner, husband of Mrs. Louise FELDNER (nee CLAUS) was born February 7, 1864, in Center township, Monroe county, Ohio. His devout parents saw that he was baptized and reared in a christian way. He came to prove himself in his true Christian character, to live his faith to die a Christian.
            He was united in holy matrimony to Miss Louise CLAUS, the daughter of Henry and Margaret Miller Claus, December 15, 1898, in Miltonsburg, Ohio, at the home of the bride. This union was blessed with six children, one of whom preceded the father in death. Reared and residing all these years in this community, Mr. Feldner was not only well known as a man of integrity and high moral principals and a faithful member of the church as well as a loving and providing husband and father.
            Apparently in the best of health and vigor, in the pride of life, and in the highest of spirits, as he appeared to St. Paul’s members the previous Sabbath day, enjoying as was his good and audible custom, the worship with his fellow believers in the house of God; he nevertheless bore silently and patiently a bodily affliction through many years. This finally caused his unexpected death. On Tuesday he underwent an operation for this which proved unsuccessful. He was called to his reward February 1, 1923, and is survived by his wife, Louise; two sons, Clarence and Elmer Feldner; three daughters, Luella, Anna Louise and Lucille Kathryn; three brothers, a sister and a great number of relatives and friends.
            The services were conducted by the pastor, Rev. Joseph P. REINIKE in St. Paul’s Evangelical church, and the interment was in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.
 
1923
Henthorne, William J.
d: Feb. 5, 1923
1923
Nalley, Obediah
d: Feb. 10, 1923
1923
Leisure, Margaret
d: Feb. 12, 1923
1923
Stewart, Ulysses G.
d: Feb. 15, 1923
1923
Hall, Martha
d: Feb. 15, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Eliza Jane SHACKLEE
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Feb. 22, 1923
            Mrs. Eliza Jane SHACKLEE, aged 97 years, one month and ten days died at the home of her son Fremont SHACKLEE on Jackson Ridge Thurs., Feb. 15, 1923.
            The remains were brought to the home of her son Alonzo SHACKLEE in Woodsfield Friday, prepared for burial by the W. P. Galbraith undertaking establishment, and forwarded to Summerfield where the funeral took place Saturday morning at the M. E. church, Rev. H. P. DOUGHERTY officiating.  Interment  in  Eastern cemetery beside her husband, Solomon SHACKLEE who died a number of years ago. The deceased was a resident of Summerfield and community for many years and held in the highest esteem by all who knew her. She is survived by six sons, Charles SHACKLEE of near Dudley, J. W. SHACKLEE of Columbus, Fremont SHACKLEE  of  whose  home  she  died,  C. A. SHACKLEE of Woodsfield, W. S. SHACKLEE of Summerfield, Ohio, one daughter, Mrs. Amanda DRAPER of Kennonsburg; several grand and great grand children and other relatives.
 
1923
John Adams
d-February 16, 1923
 
 1923X
DEATH
Name:   Samuel CHRISTMAN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Feb. 22, 1923
            Samuel CHRISTMAN, a very highly respected citizen, died of pneumonia at his home on Maple avenue, February 16, 1923, aged 59 years, 8 months and 19 days.
            He was born near Woodsfield, Ohio on May 27, 1863, the son of Lewis and Mary CHRISTMAN. He was united in holy bonds of matrimony September 8, 1887, with Miss Maude MONTGOMERY, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William MONTGOMERY. To this union four children were born - Adda, Ronald, William and Paul CHRISTMAN, who with the mother survive.
            Samuel CHRISTMAN, who was well known as a model citizen, was baptized by Elder W. W. OTEY, formerly of Beallsville, Ohio, and became a member of the Church of Christ in August 1893, and lived a faithful Christian life until called to the better world.
            Besides the widow and children, four brothers and two sisters are left to mourn his loss as follows: Andrew, Lewis, Henry and William CHRISTMAN; Mrs. Barbara DIEHL of Clinton, Missouri, and Mrs. Anna RICER.
            The funeral, conducted by his former pastor, Elder D. W. HARKINS of Columbus, Ohio took place from the Woodsfield Church of Christ last Monday afternoon and was largely attended by relatives and friends. Interment in Oaklawn cemetery. The widow and other relatives have the sincere sympathy of many friends, and the community at large realizes that one of our very best citizens has passed to the great beyond.
 
 
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Lena KNAPP
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Feb. 22, 1923
            Mrs. Lena KNAPP, wife of Daniel KNAPP, whose home was on Woodsfield Route 3, died at her home Friday morning, February 16, 1923, at 11:00 o’clock, aged 67 years. The funeral service was held in St. Paul’s Evangelical church at 1:30 p.m. Monday. The service was conducted by her pastor, Rev. Oswald FLOHR, assisted by Rev. Joseph REINIKE. The funeral was well attended considering the very cold weather and the remains were laid to rest in Oaklawn cemetery.

1923XXXXX
DEATH
Name:   Fred BOTT
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Mar. 8, 1923
            Frederic BOTT, a well known and very highly respected citizen of Lewisville, Ohio, died at the Good Samaritan Hospital in Zanesville, Ohio last Saturday, March 3, 1923, afternoon at 3:00 o’clock. He was the son of Ludwig and Katharina SHENK BOTT. He  leaves  a  wife,  one  daughter  and two sons, Charles and Irvin BOTT of Zanesville.
            He was a brother of Mr. L. D. BOTT of Eastern avenue, Woodsfield, and leaves two other brothers and three sisters, J. H. BOTT and Mrs. Chris LAUER of Columbus; Mrs. Mary KATHARY of Medina; John BOTT of Shawnee and Mrs. John BURG of New Lexington.
            The funeral will take place this (Wednesday) afternoon at 1:30.
 
A following article was written in the newspaper and provided by Eloise Lumbatis January:
            The Immortal spirit of Fred Bott life-long resident of Lewisville and a citizen of many good qualities, took its departure March 4, 1923. Mr. Bott had been in ill health for some time and underwent an operation at the Good Samaritan hospital at Zanesville, Ohio. It soon became evident that he would not recover, and the entire family wee present when his soul quietly passed away. He was born February 18, 1860. When at sixteen years of age he was confirmed and became a member of St. Peter’s Evangelical church, Lewisville. He was united in marriage to Tillie L. Weber in 1887, and to this union was added four souls, Charles H., Irvin C., of Zanesville, Zelda E. at home, and Ethel who preceded him to the Great Beyond nineteen years ago.
            We could not keep the unwelcome Angel away. In spite of all that we could do, he loosed the silver cord, and left us only the lifeless form of him we loved. He was a devoted husband and tool great interest in his children, also his only grandchild LaZora. he is not dead. His memory will remain fragrant with the passing years. Family circles are broken but love never dies. God is love, and imparts it freely to his children. Mr. Bott had many friends who will share with his family their loss.
 
 A loving father, true and kind,
One like our papa we will never find;
For us he did his very best,
May God grant him eternal rest.
 
Short  funeral services were held at the home March 7, by Rev. C. W. Cartwright, after which the remains were taken to st. Peter’s church and the sermon was delivered by his pastor, Rev. W. P. Dallmann. Interment in the family lot near the church. many words of tribute were spoken with flowers.
                       
1923
DEATH
Name:   Richard K. WALTON
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Mar. 8, 1923
            Ex-Probate Judge Richard K. WALTON, father of Ex-Mayor William Vernon WALTON of Columbus, Ohio, died at the home of his daughter Mrs. Emma V. EKSTRAND, at 3704 West 82nd street, Chicago, on February 9, 1923, aged 87 years. Mr. Walton was a native of Monroe county, served two terms as probate judge of Monroe county and has many friends here among the older citizens, who will sincerely regret to learn of his death. Mr. Walton was laid to rest by the side of his wife, Julia A. WALTON, who preceded him in death two years ago, and they are buried in the beautiful Oakwood cemetery in Chicago.
 
1923   XXXXX
DEATH
Name:   Robert Homer McCAMMON
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Mar. 8, 1923
            Robert Homer McCAMMON, son of Mrs. Cora McCAMMON, whose home is near Buchanan, died Wednesday afternoon, February 28, 1923. He was 26 years of age and is survived by two sisters and three brothers. The funeral services were conducted at the Buchanan church by the pastor, Rev. John Jay SRODES.
            Interment in Buchanan cemetery.
            Mrs. McCammon and family have the sincere sympathy of many friends.
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Alex S. STRICKLING
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Mar. 8, 1923
            Alexander S. STRICKLING, a very highly respected citizen died at his home west of Lewisville, Ohio last Monday morning, March 5, 1923, after a long illness from Bright’s disease. He leaves a wife, the former Emma J. NALLEY, and seven sons.
            The funeral will take place this (Wednesday) afternoon at 2:00 p.m. from the Woodsfield Church of Christ after which his remains will be laid to rest in Oaklawn cemetery.
            The bereaved family have the sincere sympathy of many friends. We hope to be able to give a full account of the death of this exemplary citizen in the near future.

Cline, James

1923
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Louis SULSBERGER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Mar. 15, 1923
            Mrs. Lena SULSBERGER of North Main street, Woodsfield, Ohio, died at her home Thursday, March 8, 1923, of hardening of the arteries. She had been in falling health for some time but Monday became worse until the end. Mrs. Sulsberger was born in Wheeling, West Virginia, July 26, 1849, the daughter of Francis and Caroline RICER. When a little child her parents moved to Center township. She was married December 18, 1867, to Louis SULSBERGER, Rev. F. E. Englebach performing the ceremony. To this union was born ten children, three of whom died in infancy. Her son, Dr. J. J. SULSBERGER, preceded her seven years, passing away Sept. 20, 1916. Her husband, Louis SULSBERGER, died two years ago. The children present at the funeral were, C. C. SULSBERGER of Climbing Hill, Iowa; Mrs. George GRAHAM of Bridgeport, Ohio; Mrs. Lee BRIGGS living near Woodsfield and F. O. and F. L. SULSBERGER of Woodsfield.
            The funeral took place from the home and St. Paul’s Evangelical church last Sunday afternoon, with her pastor, Rev. Joseph REINIKE in the charge, and was one of the largest funerals at the county seat in recent years.
            Mrs. Sulsberger was confirmed in the Evangelical church when quite young and was a good church member and an exemplary citizen but her chief virtues were in the home, where she reared to womanhood one of the finest families in Eastern Ohio - - a mother’s pride and a benefit to the community in which she lived. As matron at the county jail during the two terms her husband served as sheriff she was always kind and attentive to the inmates.
            The floral offerings were many and beautiful, an evidence of the high esteem in which she was held.
            Relatives from out of town who attended were, Charles RICER of Ozark, Lewis GRAHAM of Bridgeport, Mr. and Mrs. Clum BROWN of Ozark, Mrs. John BURG of New Lexington, Mrs. Mary KATHARY of Medina and Mrs. Chris LAUER of Columbus.
            The remains with E. E. Dougherty of the Woodsfield Undertaking company in charge, were laid to rest in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.
 
1923
Maggie Baker
d-March 9, 1923
 
1923
Miller, Elizabeth
d: Mar. 9, 1923
1923
Dillon, Dillon, W. A.
d: Mar. 11, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   William R. PRICE
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Mar. 15, 1923
            The funeral service for William R. PRICE, was held in the home on the corner of Paul and Church streets, Tuesday afternoon, March 10, 1923, at two o’clock. Rev. S. L. Lloyd acting pastor of the Methodist church conducted the service. The music was furnished by a male quartet of the Knights of Pythias, which rendered “Rock of Ages” and “Nearer My God to Thee.” After the service the local lodge of the K. of P. marched to the Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield as a guard of honor. The interment was according to the ritual of that order.
            Wm. R. PRICE, son of James PRICE and wife of Center township, Monroe county, Ohio, was born November 25, 1880, and died at Woodsfield, Ohio, March 10, 1923, aged 42 years, 4 months and 15 days. He was married to Miss Clara TURNER, daughter of J. W. TURNER and wife, in June 1904. To them were born two children, Pearl PRICE aged 9 years and Mabel PRICE aged 4 years. Besides these two children he leaves to mourn his death, his wife, father and mother, ten sisters and two brothers, besides a host of relatives and friends. Of his father’s family of fifteen children he is the third to pass away, two brothers having preceded him in death.
            He united with the Methodist Episcopal church at the Moffett appointment in 1903, later he was transferred to the Woodsfield church by letter.
 
1923
James G. Baker
d-March 15, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Thurman J. DeVOE
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Mar. 22, 1923
            Thurman J. DeVOE of Lewisville, Ohio died of tuberculosis at his home, Friday, March 16, 1923, at 11:30 p.m. The funeral was conducted by Pastor CARTWRIGHT in the Methodist Protestant church of Lewisville, at 9 a.m. this morning. The body was interred in the Friendship cemetery at Lewisville. Bauer and Willison in charge.
            Mr. DeVoe was a soldier in the late war, who saw real and trying service. He entered the service of the Regular Army, as a private in Headquarters troop of Division No. 1, June 23, 1918, enlisting at Woodsfield. His service was both in France and Germany. He was engaged in the Mense-Argonne, October 1-12, 1918, and again on the same section  November 5-8. From November 17, 1918, to August 21, 1919, he was with the army of occupation in Germany. He reached the United States September 5, 1919, and was discharged at Camp Meade, September 24, 1919. From that time on he spent nearly two years in the service hospitals returning to his home last April. He was born July 22, 1888, and leaves a father, three sisters and two brothers.
 
In a following article the information below is that of John Thurman* DeVoe, provided by Eloise Lumbatis January:
            John Thurman DeVoe, son of J. O. and Mary DeVoe, was born July 22, 1888, and while we lingered around his bedside Friday night, March 16, 1923, at 11:25 his soul took its flight. the great Pilot and Bishop of souls led the way through “The valley and shadow, and he did not go up alone. His mother and one sister preceded, and with them, he has obtained his release from the limitations of this world. Death is only a departure; the silver cord is loosed, the anchor is lifted, and the soul puts out to sea. Thurman was reconciled to his condition and waited with much patience the day and the hour of his departure. He is survived by his father, two brothers, Grover C. of Ashland; Walter W. of Lewisville, and three sisters, Grace G., Mae D. and Alice M. there is also a host of other relatives and friends who share willingly the loss with the family.
            Thurman entered the arm as a private in Division No. 1 June 23, 1918, and saw active service both in the Mense-Argonne engagement October 1 to 12, 1918, and again on the same Sector November 5 to 8. From November 17, 1918, to August 21, 1919, he was with the army of Occupation in Germany. He was returned to the United states and discharged from Camp Meade, September 24, 1919.
            Mr. DeVoe was a member of the Lewisville Methodist Protestant church and also an honored member of the Lewisville I. O. O. F. Lodge.
 
go to the grave; at noon from labor cease;
   rest on thy sheaves, thy harvest work is done.
Come from the heat of battle, and in peace,
   Soldier, go home; with thee the fight is won.
 
Funeral services at the Methodist Protestant church, Monday, March 19, at 9:00 A. M. by his pastor, Rev. C. W. Cartwright. Interment at the Friendship cemetery. His many friends paid a fine tribute with flowers.
 
1923
DEATH
Name:  George YOUNG
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Mar. 29, 1923
            George Young, a highly respected citizen of Woodsfield, died at the home of J. H. CHRISTY Sunday morning, March 25th, at 7:11, aged 77 years, 11 months and 15 days, following an illness from pleurisy.
            The funeral, in charge of Rev. S. P. LOYD of the M. E. Church, took place Monday, with interment in Oaklawn cemetery.
            Mr. Young, whose wife preceded him to the great beyond, was a man of many good qualities, and had many friends who were made sad by his death.    
 
1923
(Stillborn) Brooks
d-March 27, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   D. G. WORKMAN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, April 5, 1923
            David G. WORKMAN, whose home was between Beallsville and Jerusalem, Ohio, died Sunday morning, April 1, 1923. He had been suffering for two weeks from bladder trouble, but was not thought to be dangerously ill. The funeral took place at the Presbyterian church at 1:00 p.m. Tuesday and was conducted by Rev. William PARSONS of Woodsfield.
            Mr. Workman was about 54 years old, an officer in the Beallsville Presbyterian church, Superintendent of the Sunday school, and prominent in the welfare work of his community.

MARRIAGE
Names:  Mr. S. E. CHRISTMAN
and           Miss Viola BINTZ
Source:   The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, April 5, 1923
            The last March wedding of the year was that of Miss Viola BINTZ of Lewisville, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George BINTZ, and Solomon Elmer CHRISTMAN, son of Mr. and Mrs. John CHRISTMAN. The ceremony was performed Saturday, March 31, 1923, by Reverend Joseph REINICKE, pastor of St. Paul’s Evangelical church of Woodsfield.
 
 
1923
MARRIAGE
Names:  Mr. Edgar GIBBONS        
and           Miss Cecelia HUTH
Source:   The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Apr. 12, 1923
            One of the biggest and most enjoyable weddings for many a day in this county was solemnized Tuesday morning at 9:00 o’clock, at the Catholic parsonage in Miltonsburg, Ohio, by Rev. Father MATTES, when Miss Cecelia HUTH, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John HUTH, and Mr. Edgar GIBBONS, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. F. GIBBONS, were united in the holy bonds of matrimony.
            After the ceremony the bridal party left for the bride’s home near Ozark, Ohio where a very fine dinner was served, followed by dancing and a general good time was experienced. Those present from a distance were Mr. and Mrs. Charles WHITMORE and Mrs. Gertrude RAUSCH of Wheeling, West Virginia, and Mr. and Mrs. Clem HAREN and daughter Maxine of Canton, Ohio, Rev. SEEBER, and Miss Mary STILES of Woodsfield, Rev. MATTES and Miss Mary PETTERS of Miltonsburg, Ohio.
            The Spirit joins many other friends in wishing Mr. and Mrs. Gibbons a long and happy married life.
 
1923
Hall, Mary E.
d: Apr. 13, 1923

DEATH
Name: Albert Ephram MOORE
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
            Albert E. Moore died April 23, 1923 in Belmont county, Ohio. He was born March 27, 1868 in Monroe county. February 10, 1888 he married Louise Catherine KESTNER.
 
1923X
DEATH
Name:    Andy REICH
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., April 26, 1923
            Andrew Reich, one of Woodsfield’s oldest and most highly respected citizens, died at the home of his daughter and son-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. S. S. BRUBACH on South Main street last Monday morning, April 23, 1923, aged 79 years, 6 months and 10 days. He was born in Germany October 13, 1843, and came to America when about 21 years of age, and has been a citizen of Monroe county for many years, doing much good as a public officer, farmer and friend to all who knew him. His wife, the former Elizabeth CLAUS, preceded him in death, February 14, 1920, and he leaves the following children besides many other relatives and friend to mourn his death: George and William REICH, residing near Woodsfield; Mrs. John SIEGEL of Pittsburg; Mrs. Oscar FRIDAY, near Woodsfield; Mrs. Charles SULSBERGER of Iowa; Mrs. Philip GERTLER of Ozark, Ohio and Mrs. S. S. BRUBACH of Woodsfield with whom he was residing at the time of his death.
            Mr. Reich was elected Infirmary Director of Monroe county in November 1901, and reelected in 1908, serving two full terms with the best of satisfaction.
            The funeral will take place at the St. Paul’s Evangelical church this (Thursday) afternoon at 2:00 o’clock with his pastor, Rev. Joseph REINICKE in charge. Interment under directions of W. P. Galbraith in Oaklawn cemetery.
 
1923
DEATH
Name:    Joseph's COX
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Apr. 26, 1923
            Joseph's COX, father of Mrs. John HARMON of High street, Woodsfield, Ohio, died at the home of his son, W. H. COX, in Martins Ferry on April 11, 1923, aged 82 years, 4 months and 14 days.
            On January 1, 1867, Joseph's COX was united in marriage to Margaret L. DOUGHERTY, who departed this life in February 1919. To this union three children were born - William H. COX of Martins Ferry, Ohio; Mrs. John HARMON of Woodsfield, Ohio, and Isaac N. COX of Vandalia, Illinois. He also leaves to mourn his departure, 14 grandchildren, 12 great grandchildren and one brother, Daniel COX of Martins Ferry, and a host of other relatives and friends.
            Joseph's COX was a veteran of the Civil War, giving valiant service to his country under the stars and stripes from the earliest period of that great war until its close in 1865. As a citizen he was always true to his family and friends and leaves a record of a pleasing nature.
            The remains were brought to the home of Mr. and Mrs. John HARMON of Woodsfield, Ohio, thence to the home of J. C. HARMON of Graysville, where funeral services were conducted by Elder J. A. HINES of Woodsfield. Interment in the Graysville cemetery.
 
1923
Richardson, Mary E.
d: Apr. 28, 1923
 
1923
Roderick A. Buskirk
d- May 12, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Robert COATS
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., May 24, 1923
            Robert COATS of Cambridge, Ohio, son of the late Benjamin and Helen COATS of Coats Station, died at 1:00 o’clock p.m. last Sunday, May 20, 1923, at his home in that city as a result of gallstones in severe form. Mr. Coats was a native of this county and had been engaged in the railroad business for many years as conductor and was regarded by the company as one of its best and safest men. He leaves a wife and one daughter. The remains were brought home and given over to Bauer &  Willison, undertakers, and were laid to rest last Tuesday in Zion cemetery after appropriate services conducted by Elder J. A. HINES.

DEATH
Name:   Gottlieb FRANTZ
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., June 21, 1923
            Word has been received here to the effect that Gottlieb FRANTZ, a highly respected citizen of Switzerland township, this county, fell from a tree Tuesday morning while picking cherries, and his neck was broken, causing instant death. Mr. Frantz was about 70 years old. We have no further particulars.

1923
DEATH
Name:    William SMITH
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Aug. 16, 1923
            While the patriotic people were mourning of our great President Harding, Mr. William SMITH, Sr, was called in death - causing his many friends in Woodsfield additional grief of a near nature.
            William Smith was born in Center township, near Buchanan church on August 11, 1848, and died at the home of his daughter, Mrs. B. H. WILLIAMS, at 4:30 o’clock in the afternoon. Had he lived until August 11th, the anniversary of his birth, he would have been seventy-five years of age.
            In 1868, he was married to Miss Mary BORNER and with the exception of a few months of their early married life spent in Pittsburgh, they always resided in Woodsfield, where their friends included the entire citizenship.
            Of the family born to them, six children are living: They are Mrs. H. E. WILCOX of Central City, Iowa; Harry C. SMITH of Columbus, Ohio; Mrs. E. G. REISINGER of South Heights, PA; W. B. SMITH, Eugene SMITH and Mrs. B. H. WILLIAMS, all of Woodsfield.
            Mr. Smith was the last survivor of a large family, all of whom were very highly respected.
            His wife passed to her reward July 6, 1904.
            From early youth Mr. Smith was a member of the Methodist Episcopal church and his conscientious rectitude is a valued heritage left to his family and friends.
            The funeral services were held Wednesday afternoon and Saturday afternoon with services conducted at his late home by Rev. George L. DAVIS. Interment in the family lot in Oaklawn cemetery.
            Neighbor and friend of price less worth, farewell.
 
 
1923
Amanda E. Baker
d-August 12, 1923
 
1923XXXXX
BIRTH
Name:   Infant son BERY
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Aug. 23, 1923
            On Friday, August 17, 1923, the stork left a beautiful and healthy son at the home of Major and Mrs. William J. BERY on High street. Mother and babe are doing nicely. Little brother Emerson BERY has given his new brother a cordial welcome, and the Major - well we reckon he never stepped higher or seemed more dignified when serving Uncle Sam across the briny deep during the World War.
 
1923   XXXXX
DEATH
Name:   Mrs. Helen MORRIS, nee JONES
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept.  6, 1923
            Relatives of Woodsfield received a message stating that Mrs. Helen MORRIS, widow of the late Major W. T. MORRIS, died at her home in Columbus, Ohio, Tuesday morning, September 4, 1923, from ailments incident to old age as she was about 88 years old. She leaves besides other relatives, one brother and two sisters in Woodsfield - Delbert and Misses Frances and Bert JONES. As Major and Mrs. resided here during the earlier part of their lives they have many Woodsfield friends to sympathize with members of the family who survive. The funeral will take place today (Thursday.)
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Jacob REINHERR
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 6, 1923
            The funeral of the late Jacob REINHERR took place Wednesday afternoon of last week and was well attended. The remains awaiting the arrival of his daughter, Mrs. Alfred OKEY of Monmouth, Illinois, were not laid to rest in Oaklawn cemetery until Thursday morning at 10:00 o’clock when his pastor, Rev. Joseph REINICKE, the Masonic and I. O. O. F. Lodges again took part in the final ceremonies before laying a devoted brother to rest.
            Mr. Reinherr was born at Kussel in Bavaria, Germany, on July 29, 1842, and was therefore 81 years old last July 29th. He came to America with his parents when but seven years of age and settled with them at New Matamoras, Ohio, where  he  received  his  religious  training in the Evangelical church and his common school education. Later in life he learned the  baker’s  trade  and  worked  at Marietta, Pittsburgh, Wheeling, Parkersburg, Cambridge, Columbus, and other cities before locating here. Just before entering business in Woodsfield he was united in marriage with Miss Caroline WEIHE of Pittsburgh on March 30, 1869, who with four children, survive him, one son Carl REINHERR having preceded his father in death. The surviving children are as follows: Mrs. Alfred OKEY of Monmouth, Illinois; William H. REINHERR of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; Miss Anna REINHERR of the home, and Mrs. W. F. COPELAND of Athens, Ohio.
            Mr. Reinherr was a great secret society man as well as a faithful church member. He was raised to the sublime degree of Master Mason May 7, 1868, was a past master, had done much in degree work, represented his district at Grand Lodge and could repeat all the obligations in the Blue Lodge of Masons only a short time before his death. He was also a Grand Lodge representative on several occasions and was identified with the Odd Fellows Encampment and the Rebekahs, where he was equally attentive to the duties incumbent upon him.
            Among relatives from a distance at the funeral where Mrs. Alfred OKEY of Monmouth, Illinois; Will H. REINHERR of Pittsburg, Pennsylvania; Elizabeth REINHERR of Wheeling; Mrs. Elizabeth RING of Rings Mill , Ohio; Mrs. J. S. TRAVIS and son Roy and Miss Ida BUEGEL of Brownsville, Ohio.
            The floral offerings were many and beautiful, indicating the high esteem in which he was held.
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Daisy BROWN, nee GOODWIN
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 20, 1923
            The death of Mrs. Daisy GOODWIN BROWN, at Malaga, brought grief to many relatives and friends both here and throughout Monroe county. A son was born to her last Saturday, September 8, which caused her death. She was 24 years, 4 months and 15 days of age.
            Mrs. Brown was born at Malaga, Ohio, April 23, 1899, the daughter of Wilson E. and Mary P. GOODWIN. She grew to womanhood there, received her early education there and became a member of the Bush church on July 19, 1914, being baptized by Brother W. S. GIBBONS. She lived a Christian life according to, “The Will of God.” She was loved by all who knew her and especially by her school friends.
            She was united in marriage to Clarence BROWN, June 3, 1922. They made their home in Wheeling. Besides her husband and her infant son, she is survived by her parents, two sisters, two brothers and a host of relatives and friends.
            Funeral services were held at the Bush church at Malaga Tuesday and she was laid to rest in the church yard there.
 
1923
Howell, Floyd A.
d: Sept. 11, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Nelson T. HARPER
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 20, 1923
            Nelson T. HARPER, one of Monroe county’s most highly respected citizens, died at this home near Malaga, Ohio, Friday night, September 14, 1923, aged 88 years, after an illness of several years incident of old age. The funeral took place last Sunday afternoon and was very largely attended by relatives and friends from far and near. The services were conducted by Evangelist J. A. HINES and W. W. THORNBERRY. Mr. Harper is survived by the following children: Dorsey B. HARPER and Belle HARPER of the home, James O. and Ernest J. HARPER of Malaga, Ohio; Clarence HARPER of Barnesville, Ohio, and Mrs. D. C. HARDESTY of St. Clairsville, Ohio; also 32 grandchildren and 32 great grandchildren, all of whom have the sincere sympathy of many friends. Interment in Bush cemetery.
 
1923
Dillon, Martin
d: Sept. 19, 1923
1923
Myers, George W.
d: Sept. 25, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:   Jacob SIEGEL
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Sept. 27, 1923
            Jacob SIEGEL whose home is near Miltonsburg, Ohio, died on Sunday evening, aged 76. He was born in Whittenburg, Germany, the home of Martin LUTHER. He came to this country in 1865. For 8 years he was a resident of Belmont county and has spent the rest of his life in Monroe.
            He married early in life to Miss Mary FRIDAY. His wife, five daughters and three sons survive him.
            He was a member of the Evangelical church at Miltonsburg and the funeral services will be held in that church, Wednesday afternoon at 1:30.
 
1923   XXXXX
MARRIAGE
Names:   Mr. James McCOLLUM
and           Miss Ethel GREEN
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Oct. 25, 1923
            Miss Ethel GREEN, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. GREEN and Mr. James McCOLLUM, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alonzo McCOLLUM, were married last Saturday in Woodsfield by N. E. ODEN, Justice of Peace. Both are highly respected young people of Lewisville.
1923
Eilene M. Baker
d-September 28, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Isabella HAWKINS
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Oct. 25, 1923
“Today recalls sad memories
Of a loved one gone to rest.
Those who think of her today
Are those who loved her best.”
            Mrs. Isabella HAWKINS, venerable widow of the late James HAWKINS, died at the home of her son, Thaddeus HAWKINS on Jackson Ridge, Saturday night October 20, 1923, aged 92 years, 4 months and 15 days.
            Mrs. Hawkins was not only one of Monroe County’s oldest citizens, but a pioneer of modest and religious belief, whose good deeds had much to do with the evaluation of mankind and the success of her family and friends.
            While she had been practically an invalid for a number of years, news of her death came as a shock not only to her family but to all who had the pleasure of her acquaintance.
            The funeral was held last Tuesday morning by one of her old time pastors as a member of the Methodist protestant church - Rev. D. C. COBURN, of Mt. Vernon, Ohio, in compliance with a request of Mrs. Hawkins several years ago. The funeral, in charge of E. G. DOUGHERTY, manager of the Woodsfield Undertaking Company, was largely attended by relatives and friends from far and near.
            Interment in the Fairview church cemetery on Jackson ridge, by the side of her husband, who was laid to rest many years ago by Dr. D. C. COBURN.
            We join a large circle of friends in extending sympathy to the bereaved family.
            She was the best God could send -            A loving mother, faithful friend -                               And While she lies in peaceful                           sleep,
            Her memory we shall always keep.
 
1923
Leisure, Ray B.
d: Oct. 1923
1923
McVey, Augusta
d: Oct. 1, 1923
1923
Steed, William A.
d: Oct. 6, 1923
1923
Moore, William F.
d: oct. 14, 1923
1923
Turner, Unnamed
d: Oct. 19, 1923
           
1923XXXXX
MARRIAGE
Names:    Mr. Charles T. GRAMLICH
and            Miss Anna ACKERMAN
Source:   The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Oct. 25, 1923
            Miss Anna ACKERMAN daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad ACKERMAN, and Mr. Charles C. GRAMLICH, were married in Woodsfield last Saturday by Rev. George L. DAVIS, pastor of the M. E. Church. The bride is a very highly respected young lady of Woodsfield, and the groom is employed in the railroad business at Zanesville, where the happy couple are now located in a home previously furnished for them.
 
1923
Steed, Celesta J.
d: Oct. 30, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. Eliza PAYNE
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, Nov. 8, 1923
            Mrs. Eliza PAYNE, whose home was about three miles north of Graysville, Ohio, died Thursday, November 1, 1923, aged 21 years and 7 months. She leaves to mourn her loss, a devoted husband, two darling children, one aged three years, and the other 18 months also her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John KINDALL of Jackson Ridge.
            The funeral with services in charge of Elder C. L. MELLOTT and J. G. POULTON of Graysville serving as funeral director, was held last Friday. Interment in the Plainview cemetery.
            The bereaved husband, parents and children have the sincere sympathy of many friends.
1923
BIRTH
Name:    Nancy STEWARD
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Nov. 15, 1923
            Word has been receive here by the grandparents, Dr. and Mrs. G. W. STEWARD of Jerusalem, Ohio, of the birth of a baby girl, Nancy,  to Captain and Mrs. Wilfred H. STEWARD of Oakland, California. Captain Steward, is on detail there as a military instructor in Oakland Technical High School, the largest high school on the Pacific Coast.
            The spirit congratulates the young people on the arrival of the young lady at their home.
 
1923
Wilson, Anna
d: Nov. 5, 1923
 
1923
DEATH
Name:    Mrs. David WEBER
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Nov. 15, 1923
            Mrs. Mary C. WEBER died at her home on Lewisville, Ohio route 2 last Sunday morning, November 11, 1923, following a recent stroke of paralysis, aged 60 years, 9 months and 6 days. She leaves besides a devoted husband, two children, Emma and William WEBER; also many other relatives and friends.
            The funeral took place Tuesday with Rev. DOLLMAN of Lewisville in charge of services and Bauer & Willison as funeral directors.
            Services were held at the home, and at the Lewisville Evangelical church. Interment at Buchanan.
            The funeral was attended by an unusual number of relatives and friends.         
            We join in extending sympathy to the bereaved husband and other near relatives.
 
1923
Schafer, Jane
d: Nov. 19, 1923
1923
DEATH
Name:   Amelia Magdalina FRIDAY
Source: St. John’s Church records
and        The Monroe County Republican
Woodsfield, Ohio, November 29, 1923
            Amelia Magdalina FRIDAY died November 18, 1923, aged 72 years; daughter of Jacob and Margaretha KETTERER EGGER. She was born March 19, 1851. Surviving are her children: Jacob FRIDAY, Mrs. Mary FRIDAY DIXON, Mrs. Barbara FRIDAY STEED, Albert, Solomon and Samuel FRIDAY. Also surviving are her brothers, George, William and Herman EGGER, sisters, Lucetta, Barbara and Matilda EGGER.
 
1923
Weber, Jacob
d: Nov. 20, 1923

Tubaugh, A. E.
d: Nov. 25, 1923
1923
Watters, Robert N.
d: Nov. 29, 1923
 
1923   XXXXX
DEATH
Name:     Mrs. John MUTH
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Dec. 6, 1923
            Mrs. Elizabeth MUTH died at her home in Benton township, Saturday, December 1, 1923, aged 70 years and 7 days. She had been sick but a short time from Bright’s disease. Her husband preceded her in death some time ago, but she is survived by eight children and many other relatives and friends. The funeral in charge of Rev. Wm. DALLMAN of Lewisville, took place Tuesday at 11:00 o’clock a.m. Interment in St. Paul’s Evangelical cemetery on Trail Run.
 
1923
Stine, Mary I.
d: Dec. 3, 1923
923
Moore, Hazel
d: Dec. 10, 1923
1923
McCoy, Unnamed
d: Dec. 10, 1923
 
1923   XXXXX
DEATH
Name:    Miss Pearl MENKEL
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Dec. 6, 1923
            Her many friends, young and old were shocked to learn of the death of Miss Pearl MENKEL, twelve-year old daughter of Mrs. Emma MENKEL at her home on Sycamore street last Tuesday morning at 7:00 o’clock, after a short illness from scarlet fever.  Last Friday, Pearl, in usual health had given a party for her young girl friends, played Saturday with her young friends, but too sick Saturday night. A private funeral was held this (Wednesday) morning with Bauer & Willison in charge. Interment in Oaklawn cemetery. The bereaved mother and family have the sympathy of many friends.
 
1924
BIRTH
Name:    Infant male NALLEY
Source:  The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., January 3, 1914
            Mr. and Mrs. George R. NALLEY of Conner Ridge were made happy December 26, 1923, by the arrival at their home of a 10-pound baby boy. This son is a grandson of Mrs. Rosa B. KINNEY near Woodsfield and also a great grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Jere JACKSON of Woodsfield. We congratulate Mr. and Mrs. Jere JACKSON on the arrival of their grandson.
